Sec. 2-141. Appointment of Municipal Judge.
The Municipal Court of the Town shall be presided over by a Municipal Judge, appointed for a term of two (2) years by resolution of the Board of Trustees. Additional Judges as may be needed to transact the business of the Municipal Court may be appointed by the Board of Trustees for such terms as necessary.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 2-142. Compensation of Municipal Judge.
The compensation of the Municipal Judge shall be an annual salary in an amount set by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 883 §2, 2002)
Sec. 2-143. Oath of office.
Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, a Municipal Judge shall take an oath of affirmation that he or she will support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the State and the laws of the Town, and will faithfully perform the duties of his or her office.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 2-144. Original jurisdiction.
The Municipal Court shall have original jurisdiction of all cases arising under the provisions of this Code and ordinances of the Town, with full power to punish violators thereof by the imposition of such fines and penalties as are prescribed by ordinance.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 2-145. Rules of procedure.
In addition to other powers, a Municipal Judge shall have full power and authority to make and adopt rules and regulations for conducting the business of the Municipal Court, consistent with the Municipal Court Rules of Procedure promulgated by the Colorado Supreme Court.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 2-146. Contempt power.
a) When the Court finds any person to be in contempt, the Court may vindicate its dignity by imposing on the contemnor a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) and imprisonment not to exceed a term of ten (10) days.
b) In cases of indirect contempt, the alleged contemnor shall have all the rights, privileges, safeguards and protections of a defendant in a petty offense case, including but not limited to a formal written complaint, arraignment and trial by jury.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 2-147. Court clerk.
The Town Administrator, with the approval of the Board of Trustees, may appoint a person to serve as Court Clerk, whose duties shall be those assigned by the Presiding Judge. The Presiding Judge may also act as Court Clerk in accordance with state statutes.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 2-148. Municipal Court costs and fees.
a) Deferred judgment and sentence and deferred prosecution fees. In all actions in which a defendant is granted a deferred judgment and sentence, or a deferred prosecution, the defendant shall be
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 32
assessed a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) to defray the costs of preparing applicable court documents and to monitor compliance. Nothing contained in this Section shall prevent the Court from assessing additional fees if a human services agency, mental health professional or similar professional is utilized by the Court to supervise the defendant's compliance with the terms of the deferred judgment or deferred prosecution. This fee shall also apply to those sentenced to useful public service that is supervised by the Town.
b) Probation fees. In all actions in which the Court orders a defendant be placed on probation, the Court shall assess a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) against the defendant to defray the costs of monitoring the defendant's compliance with the terms of probation. Nothing contained in this Section shall prevent the Court from assessing additional fees in the event the defendant is required to undergo counseling, treatment or supervision by a human services agency, mental health professional or similar professional.
c) Bench warrant fee. In all actions in which a bench warrant is issued for the arrest of a defendant for failure to appear or failure to pay fines and costs as ordered by the Court, the Court shall assess against said defendant a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) in addition to all other fees and costs due and owing.
d) Outstanding judgment/warrant (OJW) fee. In all actions in which notice of an outstanding judgment or bench warrant is issued to the Colorado Department of Revenue, Division of Motor Vehicles, for a defendant for failure to appear, failure to pay fines or failure to otherwise perform as ordered, the Court shall assess against said defendant a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) in addition to all other fees and costs due and owing.
e) Violation training surcharge. In addition to any docket fee or other costs imposed by this Section, a surcharge on the fine imposed for violation of all municipal ordinances, including ordinance violations under the Model Traffic Code, is hereby levied in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) on each Municipal Court action resulting in a conviction, plea of guilty or no contest, or in a deferred judgment and sentence. The defendant shall pay such surcharge to the Court Clerk at the time the fine is paid, whether the defendant appears in Court or pays the fine through the mail. The Court Clerk shall deposit the money so received in a special fund, and all such surcharges collected shall be used exclusively for training Town police officers in the performance of their duties.
f) Police communication surcharge. In addition to any docket fee or other costs imposed by this Section, a surcharge on the fine imposed for violation of all municipal ordinances, including ordinance violations under the Model Traffic Code, is hereby levied in the amount of forty dollars ($40.00) on each Municipal Court action resulting in a conviction, plea of guilty or no contest, or in a deferred judgment and sentence or deferred prosecution. The Defendant shall pay such surcharge to the Court Clerk at the time the fine is paid, whether the Defendant appears in Court or pays the fine through the mail. The Court Clerk shall deposit the money so received in a special fund, and all such surcharges collected shall be used exclusively for the operation of the Mesa County 911 dispatch and communications system.
g) Docket fee. In all proceedings before the Municipal Court, a docket fee shall be charged to a defendant if a conviction is imposed. In all Municipal Court ordinance actions, the docket fee shall be levied in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). A separate docket fee in the same amount shall be charged if a defendant is found guilty of a violation of probation, deferred sentence and judgment or contempt of court.
h) Jury fee. At the time he or she demands a jury trial, the defendant shall pay a jury fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to the Court Clerk. If the defendant is subsequently found not guilty or the charges against him or her are dismissed, the jury fee shall be returned.
i) Juror fees. For attending Municipal Court, jurors shall receive the amount of six dollars ($6.00) while actually engaged on the jury and the amount of three dollars ($3.00) for attendance on the panel alone. Said fee shall be paid by the Town.
j) Witness fee. A fee in the amount of two dollars ($2.00) for each witness shall be assessed for each witness testifying at trial. Said fees shall be paid by the defendant upon his or her conviction. Witnesses shall receive the sum set forth above for testifying before the Municipal Court; provided, however, that the witnesses called to testify only to an opinion founded on special study or experiences in any branch of science or to make scientific or professional examinations and state the result thereof shall receive additional compensation, to be fixed by the Municipal Court, with reference to the value of the time employed and the degree of learning or skill required. Said fees fixed by the
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 33
Municipal Court shall be assessed against the defendant upon his or her conviction and paid to such witnesses. Any witness fee collected by the Court Clerk shall be paid to the person entitled to the witness fee, if claimed by such person. Any witness fee collected, but not claimed by a witness in the same month, shall be paid by the Court Clerk to the Town Treasurer. All unclaimed witness fees shall become the property of the Town and shall not be refunded. If a fee claimed by a witness has not previously been collected by the Court Clerk, the Town shall pay the witness claimant if said claim was submitted in a timely manner.
k) Mileage fee. All witnesses and jurors shall receive an amount of fifty cents ($0.50) per mile for each mile actually and necessarily traveled in going from their places of residence to the Municipal Court; provided, however, that no witness shall receive mileage fees unless such witness claims the same before the adjournment of the Municipal Court. Mileage fees shall be paid by the Town. This Subsection shall not apply to an officer of the court who attends in his or her official capacity, including clerks, sheriffs, bailiffs and police officers.
l) Administrative fee. An administrative fee to cover extraordinary court expenses and personnel time in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be assessed to a defendant for providing proof of insurance to the Court after a citation has been issued, resulting in dismissal of the citation. This fee is to defray the costs of preparing applicable court documents.
m) Prosecution surcharge. In all proceedings before the Municipal Court, a prosecution surcharge shall be charged to a defendant if a conviction is imposed following trial to assist the Town in providing prosecution services. The defendant shall pay such surcharge to the Court Clerk at the time judgment is entered, and the Court Clerk shall deposit the money so received in a special fund. All such surcharges collected shall be used exclusively for prosecution services. In applicable Municipal Court ordinance actions, the prosecution surcharge is hereby levied in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). A separate prosecution surcharge in the same amount shall be charged if a defendant is found guilty of a violation of probation, deferred judgment and sentence or contempt of court.
n) Certified letter fee. In addition to any docket fee or other costs imposed by this Section, a certified letter fee on the fine imposed for violation of all municipal ordinances, including ordinance violations under the Model Traffic Code is hereby levied in the amount of six dollars ($6.00) for each certified letter sent directed to the defendant by the Court Clerk or Court Administrator. Such fees shall be levied when costs are incurred in each Municipal Court action resulting in a conviction, plea of guilty or no contest, or in a deferred judgment and sentence or deferred prosecution. The defendant shall pay such surcharge to the Court Clerk at the time the fine is paid, whether the defendant appears in Court or pays the fine through the mail.
o) Miscellaneous fees. In addition to the fees listed above, the Municipal Court Judge in his or her discretion may impose reasonable fees on a defendant if such defendant fails to appear for a required court appearance, fails to appear at trial, or for other expenses directly incurred by the Municipal Court in a defendant's case, even if a bench warrant is not issued.
(Ord. 10 §1, 2013)
Sec. 2-149. Collection of fines, fees, penalties and restitution.
a) The Town Administrator is authorized to use any lawful method of collecting fines, fees, default judgments, personal recognizance bond forfeitures, restitution and civil penalties due from any person assessed such sums by the Palisade Municipal Court, including reasonable costs of collection. The Town shall be entitled to receive the reasonable costs of collection in addition to the amounts otherwise due and payable, and interest at the statutory rate for unpaid civil judgments. "Reasonable costs of collection" shall include, without limitation, the fees and costs of the Town Attorney, or a private counsel retained by the Town, or a collection agency retained by the Town, but such fees and costs shall not exceed twenty-five percent (25%) of the amount collected.
b) In the event a defendant fails to pay any fine, fee, penalty, cost, restitution, or other amount assessed by the Municipal Judge by the date so ordered, the Municipal Judge may refer a portion or all of the unpaid amount to a collection agency for collection, and the Municipal Judge may order the defendant to pay an additional amount not to exceed twenty-five percent (25%) of the amount collected as reasonable costs of collection. The Municipal Judge shall have such authority regardless of the date upon which the fine, penalty, cost, fee, or restitution order was issued.
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 34
(Ord. 2017-03, §1)
Secs. 2-150—2-160. Reserved.
ARTICLE VII Police Department
Sec. 2-161. Creation; composition.
Sec. 2-162. Departmental rules and regulations.

Sec. 2-161. Creation; composition.
There is hereby created a Police Department for the Town which shall consist of one (1) Chief of Police and as many police officers as may from time to time be deemed necessary for the safety and good order of the Town.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 2-162. Departmental rules and regulations.
The Police Department shall be operated and managed in accordance with such departmental rules and regulations as may from time to time be adopted by the Town Administrator.
(Ord. 02 §1, 2013)
Sec. 2-163. Chief of police; powers and duties.
a) It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to:
1. See that the ordinances of the Town and the laws of the State are duly enforced and the rules and regulations of the Police Department obeyed, and perform such duties as may be required by the Board of Trustees and Town Administrator.
2. Direct the operations of the Police Department, subject to the rules and regulations thereof.
3. Has the authority to hire, promote, increase or decrease compensation, discipline, suspend or dismiss employees assigned to the Police Department as provided by law or ordinance.
b) Before entering upon the duties of such office, the Chief of Police shall take and subscribe to an oath that he or she will support the Constitution and laws of the State, the Constitution of the United States and ordinances of the Town, and that he or she will faithfully perform the duties of the office upon which he or she is about to enter.
(Ord. 02 §2, 2013)
Sec. 2-164. Duties of police officers.
All members of the Police Department shall have power and duties as follows:
1. They shall perform all duties required by the Chief of Police.
2. They shall suppress all riots, disturbances and breaches of the peace and apprehend all disorderly persons in the Town, and shall pursue and arrest any person fleeing from justice in any part of the State.
3. They shall be the enforcement officers of the Town and shall see that the provisions of the ordinances of the Town and the laws of the State are complied with. They shall arrest without process all persons engaged in the violation in their presence of any provision of the ordinances of the Town or the laws of the State.
4. They shall execute and return all writs and process to them directed by the Municipal Judge in any case arising under a Town ordinance, and they may serve the same in any part of the County.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 35
Sec. 2-165. Oath.
Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, each police officer shall take and subscribe an oath that he or she will support the Constitution and laws of the State, the Constitution of the United States and the ordinances of the Town, and that he or she will faithfully perform the duties of the office upon which he or she is about to enter.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 2-166. Code Compliance Officer—Established.
There is hereby established the position of Town of Palisade Code Compliance Officer which shall be under the administrative and operational control of the Police Chief and Community Development Director. Such Code Compliance Officer shall have the power, together with the Community Development Director and Town Attorney, to enforce all terms and provisions contained in the Town's Land Development Code, as well as the terms and conditions of any permits or other land use approvals granted pursuant to such Land Development Code. Such Code Compliance Officer shall also have the authority, together with the Town Attorney and members of the Palisade Police Department, to enforce provisions contained within Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation, and Animals, and Article III of Chapter 8, Junked and Abandoned Vehicles, as well as such other provisions of the Town of Palisade Municipal Code as may be determined from time to time by the Board of Trustees. The Code Compliance Officer shall have the authority to issue notices of violation, compliance orders, and may issue citations or summons and complaints in Palisade Municipal Court. Provided, however, such Code Compliance Officer need not be a "peace officer" as defined in Title 18, C.R.S., and if the Code Compliance Officer is not a "peace officer," shall not be permitted to carry a firearm while on duty or conduct arrests.
(Ord. 2015-09, §1)
Sec. 2-167. Designation of Code Compliance Officer.
The Chief of Police shall designate one (1) or more persons to serve as the Town of Palisade Code Compliance Officer(s). Compensation for the person(s) serving as Code Compliance Officer shall be as determined from time to time by the Board of Trustees, pursuant to the Town's personnel policies and annual budget.
(Ord. 2015-09, §2)
Sec. 2-168. Liability of Code Enforcement Officer.
The Code Compliance Officer, acting in good faith and without malice in the discharge of his/her duties, shall not thereby render himself/herself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act or by reason of any act or omission in the discharge of his/her duties. Any suit brought against the Code Compliance Officer because of an alleged act or omission performed by him/her in the enforcement of the Town of Palisade ordinances shall be defended by the Town of Palisade until final termination of such proceedings, and any judgment resulting therefrom shall be assumed by the Town of Palisade in accordance with the Colorado Governmental Immunity Act, Article 10 of Title 24, C.R.S.
(Ord. 2015-09, §3)
Secs. 2-169—2-180. Reserved.

Sec. 2-181. Fire Department established; goals.
a) The Palisade Volunteer Fire Department, hereinafter referred to as the Fire Department, is established and shall also include an emergency medical response unit.
b) The goals of the Fire Department shall be the preservation and protection of life and property through prevention of fire, minimization of fire hazard and the suppression and extinguishment of fires. The Fire Department may also perform medical emergency services.
(Prior code 8.01.010; Ord. 652, 1991)
Sec. 2-182. Fire Department organization.
a) The Fire Department shall be a department of the Town government and shall be administered and operated as such under the purview of the Town Administrator.
b) The Fire Department shall consist of a Fire Chief and an Assistant Fire Chief and as many volunteer firefighters and emergency medical personnel as deemed appropriate by the Board of Trustees.
c) The Fire Chief shall be appointed by the Town Administrator by an appropriate selection process established by the Town Administrator. The Fire Chief shall establish residency within the Fire District within three (3) months of promotion or hire.
d) The Assistant Fire Chief shall be appointed by the Town Administrator by an appropriate selection process established by the Town Administrator.
e) The Fire Chief, or Assistant Fire Chief when appropriate, shall have authority and control over the Fire Department and its emergency medical response unit.
(Prior code 8.01.020; Ord. 652, 1991; Ord. 825, 1999)
Sec. 2-183. Fire Department membership.
a) Volunteer firefighters and emergency medical personnel may be appointed by the Fire Chief through a selection process established by the Town Administrator. All new appointees are subject to approval by the Town Administrator.
b) By May 1 of each year, the Fire Chief shall provide the Town Administrator with a list of current members and shall update this list as needed to reflect resignations or retirements.
c) The Town Administrator may terminate any volunteer firefighter or emergency medical person through a process established by the Town Administrator.
(Prior code 8.01.030; Ord. 652, 1991)
Sec. 2-184. Contracts and mutual aid agreements.
The Board of Trustees may enter into contracts with public and private entities for fire protection and emergency medical services and mutual aid agreements with other fire districts to provide fire protection and medical emergency services.
(Prior code 8.01.040; Ord. 652, 1991)
Sec. 2-185. Fire Chief; duties and powers.
a) The Fire Chief is designated as the chief administrative officer of the Fire Department. The Fire Chief is directly responsible to the Town Administrator.
b) The duties of the Fire Chief are to efficiently and effectively manage the operation of the Department and to serve as the daily liaison between the Fire Department and the Town Administrator. The Fire Chief shall also prepare and submit such documents as are required in this Article and conduct appropriate training programs consistent with Section 24-33.5-1204 et seq., C.R.S., and Section 31-30-415(8)(a), C.R.S.
c) The Fire Chief has the following powers:
1. The Fire Chief or the ranking officer at fire scenes shall have control of persons present at fires;
2. He or she may prescribe limits in the vicinity of any fire within which no person may enter, except members of the Fire Department, police officers and such other persons as may be admitted by the officers of such departments;
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 37
3. He or she shall have power to summon any person present at a fire to aid in extinguishing the fire and removing and protecting property. It shall be unlawful for any person to neglect or refuse to obey such orders. However, no person shall be bound to obey such officer unless the official character of the officer is known or made known to such person;
4. He or she shall have power, if in his or her judgment he or she may deem it necessary, to order any buildings or structures in close proximity to a fire in progress to be torn down, blown up or otherwise disposed of for the purpose of checking a conflagration, but shall not unnecessarily or recklessly destroy or injure any building or other property; and
5. He or she shall prescribe the duties of all members of the Fire Department.
a) In the absence or disability of the Fire Chief, the Assistant Fire Chief shall have the duties and powers of the Fire Chief.
(Prior code 8.01.050; Ord. 652, 1991)
Sec. 2-186. Reimbursement to volunteers.
Members of the Fire Department shall be reimbursed for expenses for each fire or rescue call answered. The amount of the reimbursement shall be established by resolution of the Board of Trustees and may be amended when deemed necessary.
(Prior code 8.01.070; Ord. 652, 1991
Sec. 2-187. Formation of a volunteer fire department association.
a) The Fire Department may organize its members and/or other interested persons in a support organization or association.
b) The association shall be advisory to the Board of Trustees through the Town Administrator and shall have no authority regarding official fire department administrative, operational or financial matters.
c) The association may donate funds to the Town to purchase or share in the purchase of fire department equipment. The association may also purchase fire department equipment and donate said equipment directly to the Town to be used by the Fire Department.
(Prior code 8.01.080; Ord. 652, 1991)
Sec. 2-188. Charges for services.
a) The Town Administrator shall periodically review the current charges for fire protection or emergency medical services. Through the Town Administrator, the Fire Department may recommend rate changes for services to the Board of Trustees.
b) It shall be the policy of the Board of Trustees to establish by ordinance rates for services, including emergency medical services, in such a manner as to recover one hundred percent (100%) of the cost of operating and consumable supplies.
c) Fees for emergency services, such as base rate, mileage, oxygen, I.V. monitor, emergency procedures and supplies are stated in the fee schedule.
(Prior code 8.01.090; Ord. 652, 1991; Ord. 790 §1, 1998; Ord. 883 §3, 2002)
Sec. 2-189. Palisade volunteer fire department pension board.
a) A Board of Trustees of the Volunteer and Career Firefighter Pension Fund shall be created.
b) The Board shall consist of the following members:
1. The Mayor for a term equal to the Mayor's tenure as Mayor;
2. The Town Treasurer for a term equal to the Town Treasurer's tenure with the municipality;
3. Two (2) persons to be selected by the Palisade Rural Fire Protection District; and
4. Three (3) Fire Department members of the entire membership of the Fire Department serving the municipality who are elected by the Fire Department members for three-year terms.
c) The Board shall elect the following officers:
1. President.
2. Secretary.
3. The Town Treasurer shall serve as the ex officio treasurer of the Board.
4. The duties of the Board shall be:
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 38
a. To manage, use and disburse monies in the fund according to its rules and bylaws set by the Board and in accordance with state law;
b. Shall supervise and control the fund; and
c. May take all necessary steps and pursue all necessary remedies to preserve the fund.
(Ord. 655, 1991; Ord. 841 §§1—4, 2000; Ord. 03 §1, 2013)
Secs. 2-190—2-200. Reserved.
ARTICLE IX Planning and Zoning Commissions
Sec. 2-201. Created; Planning Commission to serve as Zoning Commission; statutory authority.
Sec. 2-202. Qualifications of members.
Sec. 2-203. Planning Commission; composition and term of office.
Sec. 2-204. Organization, meetings and rules.

Sec. 2-201. Created; Planning Commission to serve as Zoning Commission; statutory authority.
Pursuant to the authority conferred by Chapter 31, C.R.S., there shall be created a Planning Commission and a Zoning Commission for the Town. The members of the Planning Commission shall also serve and are hereby appointed as the Zoning Commission.
(Prior code 18.20.010; Ord. 883 §4, 2002)
Sec. 2-202. Qualifications of members.
All members of the Planning and Zoning Commissions shall be bona fide residents of the Town, and if any member ceases to reside in the Town, his or her membership shall immediately terminate. All at-large members of such Commissions shall serve as such without compensation, and shall hold no other municipal office.
(Prior code 18.20.020; Ord. 2011-06, §1(I))
Sec. 2-203. Planning Commission; composition and term of office.
The Board of Trustees shall either assume all responsibilities and perform all duties of the Planning Commission or may appoint a Planning Commission which shall be constituted as follows: The Planning Commission shall be eight (8) members. One (1) member shall be elected official of the Town appointed by the Board of Trustees who shall be an ex officio member of the Commission and shall serve during his or her respective tenure or until replaced by action of the Board of Trustees. The ex officio member shall not be a voting member of the Commission and his/her attendance shall not be counted towards determining a quorum of the Commission. In addition to the ex-officio member, the Commission shall have seven (7) at-large members. The additional seven (7) members shall be residents of the Town, appointed by the Board of Trustees. The term for each appointed member shall be four (4) years or until his or her successor takes office, except that the respective terms of the members first appointed shall be as follows: three (3) members for a term of two (2) years and four (4) members for a term of four (4) years. The respective terms of the members first appointed shall be fixed and designated by the Board of Trustees at the time of appointment.
(Ord. 646, 1991; Ord. 746, 1996; Ord. 2011-06, §1(II); Ord. 2018-04, §1)
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 39
Sec. 2-204. Organization, meetings and rules.
a) In the event the Board of Trustees has determined to serve in the capacity of the Planning Commission, the functions and duties of the Planning Commission shall be performed during regular or special meetings of the Board of Trustees.
b) At such time as the Board of Trustees has appointed individuals to serve in the capacity of the Planning Commission, said Commission shall elect its chairman from among the appointed members and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of the chairman shall be one (1) year, with eligibility for reelection. Each Commission shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting in each month and such meetings may be held consecutively on the same date. Each Commission shall adopt rules for transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a public record.
c) The Town Clerk shall serve as Secretary to the Planning Commission. The Clerk shall either take the minutes or cause them to be taken. The minutes shall be presented to the Planning Commission at its next meeting. Copies of the minutes will be provided to the Board of Trustees as soon as practicable following their approval by the Planning Commission.
(Prior code 18.20.040; Ord. 2011-06, §1(III); Ord. 2011-07 §1)
Sec. 2-205. Staff and finances.
The expenditures of the Commission shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the Board of Trustees, which shall provide the funds, equipment and accommodations necessary for the Commission's work. Town staff shall provide assistance to the Planning Commission as needed or requested by the Planning Commission and at the direction of the Board of Trustees.
(Prior code 18.20.050; Ord. 2011-06, §1(IV))
Sec. 2-206. Powers and duties; statutory authority.
Each Commission shall have all the powers and all the duties specified by Chapter 31, C.R.S., together with any other duties or authority which may hereafter be conferred upon them by state laws. The performance of such duties and the exercise of such authority are to be subject to each and all of the limitations expressed in such legislative enactment or enactments.
(Prior code 18.20.060; Ord. 883 §5, 2002)
Sec. 2-207. Planning commission; purpose, powers and duties.
In the preparation of a master plan, the Planning Commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of present conditions and future growth of the Town, with due regard to its relations to neighboring territory. The plan shall be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the Town and its environs, which will, in accordance with present and future needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development; including among other things, adequate provision for traffic, the promotion of safety from fire, floodwater and other dangers, adequate provision for light and air, the promotion of healthful and convenient distribution of population, the promotion of good civic design and arrangement, wise and efficient expenditure of public funds and the adequate provision of public utilities and other public requirements.
(Prior code 18.20.070)
Sec. 2-208. Zoning commission; purpose, powers and duties.
The Zoning Commission shall prepare its regulations in accordance with a comprehensive plan designed to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire, panic, floodwater and other dangers; to promote health and general welfare; to provide adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of population; and to facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewage, schools, parks and other public requirements. Such regulations shall be made with reasonable consideration, among other things, as to the character of the district and its particular uses, and with a view to conserving the value of the buildings and encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the Town.
(Prior code 18.20.080)
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 40
Sec. 2-209. Planning commission, zoning commission or planning and zoning commission; removal of member.
Pursuant to Section 31-23-203(4), C.R.S., members of the Planning, Zoning or Planning and Zoning Commission may be removed upon a majority vote of the Board of Trustees after a public hearing for the following reasons:
1. A commissioner misses three (3) consecutive meetings without notice to the Commission,
2. A commissioner embarks upon a course of action which poses a conflict of interest in a majority of the business transacted by the Commission,
3. A commissioner enters into a legal action against the Town,
4. A member of the immediate family (spouse, child, parent) or cohabitant sits on the Board of Trustees ,or
5. For cause.
(Ord. 837 §1, 2000)
Secs. 2-210—2-220. Reserved.
ARTICLE X Board of Zoning Adjustment
Sec. 2-221. Created; board of adjustment defined.
Sec. 2-222. Composition.
Sec. 2-223. Term of office; vacancy filling.
Sec. 2-224. Chairman.
Sec. 2-225. Expenses authorized when.
Sec. 2-226. Removal of members authorized when.
Sec. 2-227. Powers and duties designated; procedure for granting variances and for appeals to board of adjustment.
Sec. 2-228. Appeals from board of adjustment decisions; time limit.
Secs. 2-229—2-240. Reserved.
Sec. 2-221. Created; board of adjustment defined.
A Board of Zoning Adjustment is hereby created. All further reference to the Board of Zoning Adjustment in this Code shall hereafter be made to "the Board of Adjustment."
(Prior code 18.84.010)
Sec. 2-222. Composition.
The Board of Trustees shall be the Board of Adjustment unless the Board of Trustees desires to appoint a separate board, then the following sections shall be in effect.
(Prior code 18.84.020; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 2-223. Term of office; vacancy filling.
One (1) member shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year, two (2) for a term of two (2) years and two (2) for a term of three (3) years. Thereafter, all appointments to the Board of Adjustment shall be made for terms of three (3) years each. When vacancies occur prior to the expiration of a regular term, they shall be filled in the same manner as regular appointments, but such members shall serve only until the expiration of the term in which the vacancy occurred.
(Prior code 18.84.030)
Sec. 2-224. Chairman.
The members of the Board of Adjustment shall elect from among their number a chairman to serve for a term of one (1) year.
(Prior code 18.84.040)
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 41
Sec. 2-225. Expenses authorized when.
In the performance of its duties, the Board of Adjustment may incur such expenses as shall be authorized by the Board of Trustees, but no member shall receive any compensation for his or her services.
(Prior code 18.84.050)
Sec. 2-226. Removal of members authorized when.
The Board of Trustees shall have the power to remove any member of the Board of Adjustment for cause after public hearings.
(Prior code 18.84.060)
Sec. 2-227. Powers and duties designated; procedure for granting variances and for appeals to board of adjustment.
The Board of Adjustment shall have the following powers and duties:
1. To meet at the call of the chairman, by his or her request, by the request of the Planning and Zoning Enforcement Officer, or by any party wishing to appeal the decision of the same;
2. To adopt any rules necessary to transact the Board of Adjustment's business or to expedite its function or powers so long as they are not inconsistent with the provisions of this Code;
3. To vote upon the granting of an adjustment to requirements of the zoning ordinance, which vote must require the concurrence of more than one-half (½) the members of the Board of Adjustment in order to revise an order of the Planning and Zoning Enforcement Officer;
4. To keep minutes of the proceedings of each meeting, which shall be filed in the office of the Board of Adjustment, which may designate the Planning and Zoning Enforcement Officer to keep such files, and which shall be of public record;
5. To permit the public to attend and to be heard at all of its meetings;
6. To notify in writing the Planning and Zoning Enforcement Officer, the owner involved and the Planning Commission of all decisions made, resolutions passed, hearings scheduled or permits authorized;
7. To publish notice of, cause to be published, or cause the property to be posted at least ten (10) days prior to the date of hearings, where such hearings are deemed necessary by the Board of Adjustment;
8. To interpret the Land Development Code, including any uncertainty as to boundary location or meaning of wording, so long as this interpretation is not contrary to the purpose and intent of the ordinance codified in this Chapter;
9. To grant variances from the provisions of the Land Development Code, but only where a majority of the following conditions are found to exist:
a. That the variance would not authorize any use other than uses enumerated as use-by-right in the district;
b. That an unnecessary hardship to the owner could be shown to occur if the provisions of the Land Development Code were literally followed;
c. That the circumstances found to constitute a hardship either were not created by the owner, or were in existence as of January 14, 1975, are not due to nor are the result of general conditions in the district, and cannot reasonably be corrected;
d. That the variance would not injure the value or use of, or prevent the proper access of light and air to, the adjacent properties; and/or
e. That the variance would not be out of harmony with the intent and purpose of the Land Development Code; and
10. The Board of Adjustment shall act in strict accordance with all of the other applicable laws of the State and the County. All appeals to the Board of Adjustment shall be in writing and on such a form as shall be prescribed by the Board of Adjustment. Each appeal shall be first filed with the Town Clerk along with a check or cash from the applicant in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), representing a nonrefundable fee to defray the costs and expenses incurred by reason of the appeal. No appeal shall be considered until or unless the fee provided for in this Section has been paid. Every appeal shall indicate what provision of the Land Development Code is involved, what relief from these provisions is being sought, and the grounds upon which such an appeal is being sought, as required
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 42
in Subsection (9) of this Section. Upon receipt of the appeal and the fee, the Town Clerk shall transmit the appeal to the chairman of the Board of Adjustment, who shall then, within ten (10) days of the receipt of the appeal, schedule a meeting of the Board of Adjustment for the purpose of reviewing the requested appeal. At the same time, a copy of the requested appeal shall be transmitted to the Planning Commission for an opinion, which opinion shall be returned to the Board of Adjustment before the date set for hearing the appeal. Failure of the Planning Commission to return the requested opinion shall be considered as its approval of the Board of Adjustment's granting of the requested appeal. Notification of the decisions of the Board of Adjustment shall then be made in accordance with Subsection (9) of this Section.
(Prior code 18.84.070; Ord. 2008-08 §1)
Sec. 2-228. Appeals from board of adjustment decisions; time limit.
Any further appeal from the decision of the Board of Adjustment may be made to the Board of Trustees, then to the courts as provided by law; provided, however, that such appeal is made prior to sixty (60) days following the date of the notification of the Board of Adjustment's decision.
(Prior code 18.84.080)
Secs. 2-229—2-240. Reserved.
ARTICLE XI Community Center Board
Sec. 2-241. General provisions.
Sec. 2-242. Officers and employees; chairman; vice chairman and secretary.
Sec. 2-243. Powers of board.
Secs. 2-244—2-260. Reserved.
Sec. 2-241. General provisions.
a) Community Center Board. There is created a board (hereafter the "Board") to advise the Town of the operation and maintenance of the following described property as a community center for the Town:
1. Blocks 1 and 4, Hottes Addition, Palisade, Colorado, including a building known as the Veterans or Legion Memorial Building, a Community Building.
2. The Board shall consist of four (4) members. The Board of Trustees shall appoint two (2) members, and the Palisade Veterans Memorial, Inc. shall appoint two (2) members.
b) Terms of members of Board. The terms of the initial members of the Board shall be as follows: one (1) member appointed by each of the Town and Palisade Veterans Memorial, Inc., shall serve for a one-year term; one (1) member appointed by each of the Town and Palisade Veterans Memorial, Inc., shall serve for a two-year term; one (1) member appointed by each of the Town and Palisade Veterans Memorial, Inc., shall serve for a three-year term; and the at-large member shall serve for a three-year term. After the initial terms for the various members have expired, every member thereafter appointed shall serve for a three-year term. The methods of appointing new members, or of replacing members who do not finish their terms, shall be in the discretion of the body, Board or organization making the appointment. The body, Board or organization having the power to appoint a member or members to the Board shall have the right to appoint alternate members to serve on the Board in the temporary absence of any regular meeting of the Board.
c) Meetings of the Board. The Board may conduct regular meetings as deemed necessary so long as all members are notified of said meetings.
d) Minutes. The secretary shall cause all minutes of the meetings of the Board to be kept and shall, as soon as possible after each meeting, provide a copy of the minutes to each member of the Board.
e) Voting; quorum; required votes. Each member of the Board shall have one (1) vote. Four (4) members of the Board present shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of transacting business. The affirmative votes of a majority of the Board members present shall be required to take any action by the Board.
f) Bylaws. The Board may adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations as necessary for the conduct of its meetings and affairs.
(Prior code 12.20.010; Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 806 §§1—3, 1999; Ord. 883 §6, 2002)
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 43
Sec. 2-242. Officers and employees; chairman; vice chairman and secretary.
The Board shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman and a secretary from its members. Said officers shall perform the duties normal for said offices and such other duties as may be imposed by the Board.
(Prior code 12.20.020)
Sec. 2-243. Powers of board.
a) General powers. The Board shall exercise, in the manner herein provided, all powers delegated to it by the Town, and all incidental, implied, express or necessary powers from the accomplishment of the purposes of this Article and not otherwise inconsistent with the provisions of this Article.
b) Specific powers subject to approval by Town.
1. Subject to the provisions of subparagraph (2), the Board shall be authorized to:
a. Establish general guidelines for the use, maintenance and operation of the community center; and
b. Set the rates to be charged for the use of the community center by the various users of the community center.
2. As soon as is practicable after the creation of the Board, the Board shall promulgate general guidelines for the use of the community center and shall establish rates to be charged for the use of the community center by the various users of the community center. These guidelines and rates shall then be submitted to the Board of Trustees for approval. The Board of Trustees shall hold such hearings as may be required by law or deemed necessary by the Board of Trustees concerning these guidelines and rates. After such hearings, the Board of Trustees may approve and adopt such guidelines and rates as submitted by the Board, or may request the Board to revise said guidelines or rates and resubmit them to the Board of Trustees for approval. After the initial guidelines and rates have been adopted and approved, any changes proposed to be made by the Board to the guidelines or rates shall be submitted by the Board to the Board of Trustees for approval, in a like manner as set forth above. In addition, after the initial guidelines and rates have been adopted and approved, the Board of Trustees may initiate changes to said guidelines or rates, and shall hold such hearings on these changes as may be required by law or deemed necessary by the Board of Trustees.
c) Specific powers delegated to Board. The Board shall be delegated the following powers by the Town, which powers may be exercised by the Board without the prior approval of the Board of Trustees: to establish specific policies and guidelines for the use, maintenance and operation of the community center to implement the general guidelines adopted with the approval of the Board of Trustees pursuant to Subsection (b) of this Section.
(Prior code 12.20.030; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Secs. 2-244—2-260. Reserved.
ARTICLE XII Park and Recreation Advisory Board
Sec. 2-261. Creation.
Sec. 2-262. Appointment; removal; qualifications.
Sec. 2-263. Term of office; vacancies.
Sec. 2-264. Compensation.
Sec. 2-265. Duties and responsibilities.

Sec. 2-261. Creation.
There is created and established a Town Park and Recreation Advisory Board, to be known as the "Park and Recreation Advisory Board of the Town of Palisade," which shall operate in accordance with and subject to the provisions, duties and limitations of this Article.
(Ord. 2014-04, §1)
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 44
Sec. 2-262. Appointment; removal; qualifications.
One (1) member shall be an elected official of the Town appointed by the Board of Trustees who shall be an ex officio member of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board and shall serve during his or her respective official tenure or until replaced by action of the Board of Trustees. The ex officio member shall not be a voting member of the Board and his/her attendance shall not be counted towards determining a quorum of the Board. In addition to the ex-officio member, the Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall consist of nine (9) members appointed by the Board of Trustees. Membership shall be representative of the various recreational activities prevalent in the Town. Members need not be residents of the Town. Members shall serve at the pleasure of the Board of Trustees and may be removed from the Park and Recreation Advisory Board with or without cause by a majority vote of the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2014-04, §1; Ord. No. 2018-08, §1)
Sec. 2-263. Term of office; vacancies.
The term of the members shall be three (3) years, except that the term of two (2) of the members initially appointed shall be only one (1) year; the term of two (2) members initially appointed shall be for two (2) years; and the term of the remaining three (3) members initially appointed shall be for three (3) years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any appointed member, a successor shall be appointed by the Board of Trustees to serve the unexpired portion of the term. Upon expiration of their terms, members may be reappointed to the Park and Recreation Advisory Board in the discretion of the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2014-04, §1)
Sec. 2-264. Compensation.
Members of the Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 2014-04, §1)
Sec. 2-265. Duties and responsibilities.
The Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
1. To study, investigate and recommend to the Board of Trustees the adoption of a plan for the operation, improvement and maintenance of the Town's recreation programs and facilities.
2. To bring to the attention of the Board of Trustees any matter pertaining to the Town's recreation programs and facilities.
3. To perform such other and further duties and responsibilities with respect to the Town's recreation programs and facilities as may, from time to time, be delegated by the Board of Trustees, or which are provided for by Town ordinance.
(Ord. 2014-04, §1)
Sec. 2-266. Operation.
The Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall elect officers and shall fix the term of such officers. The Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall keep contemporaneous minutes of its meetings, inclusive of discussions, votes and actions taken therein. Copies of all minutes shall be forwarded to the Board of Trustees. Four (4) members of the Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Town staff, including the Town Administrator and Public Works Director, shall provide assistance to the Park and Recreation Advisory Board as needed and at the direction of the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2014-04, §1)
Sec. 2-267. Meetings.
The Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall meet at the Town Hall in the Council Chambers on such dates as the Park and Recreation Advisory Board may determine. The Board of Trustees may vote to remove any member of the Park and Recreation Advisory Board who is absent from three (3) successive meetings. All meetings of the Park and Recreation Advisory Board shall be subject to the same open meeting laws and requirements as are applicable to the meetings of the Board of Trustees. In
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 45
addition to notice requirements provided under state law, notice of all Park and Recreation Advisory Board meetings shall be delivered to members of the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2014-04, §1)
Sec. 2-268. Rules and regulations.
The Park and Recreation Advisory Board may adopt rules and regulations governing its operation; provided, however, that no such rule or regulation, or any amendment thereto, shall become effective until such rule, regulation or amendment has been approved by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2014-04, §1)
Secs. 2-269—2-280. Reserved.
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. 2014-04, adopted March 11, 2014, amended Art. XII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. XII, §§ 2-261—2-268 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. 2008-10, §1.
ARTICLE XIII Tourism Advisory Board
Sec. 2-281. Creation.
Sec. 2-282. Appointment; removal; qualifications.
Sec. 2-283. Term of office; vacancies.
Sec. 2-284. Compensation.
Sec. 2-285. Duties and responsibilities.
Sec. 2-286. Operation.
Sec. 2-287. Meetings.
Sec. 2-288. Rules and regulations.
Secs. 2-289—2-300. Reserved.
Sec. 2-281. Creation.
There is created and established a Tourism Advisory Board, to be known as the "Palisade Tourism Advisory Board," which shall operate in accordance with and subject to the provisions, duties and limitations of this Article.
(Ord. 2007-14 §1)
Sec. 2-282. Appointment; removal; qualifications.
The Tourism Advisory Board shall consist of not more than eleven (11) or fewer than five (5) members appointed by the Board of Trustees. Where practicable, membership shall consist of representatives from various tourism-related businesses, including the lodging industry, food service, retail, the recreational industry, the agricultural industry and the winery industry. At least two (2) members shall be Palisade residents and one (1) member a Palisade Trustee. Other members need not be residents of the Town. Members shall serve at the pleasure of the Board of Trustees and may be removed from the Tourism Advisory Board with or without cause by a majority vote of the Board of Trustees. Alternate members may be appointed by the Board of Trustees to serve in the absence of regular members.
(Ord. 2007-14 §1; Ord. 2009-02 §1)
Sec. 2-283. Term of office; vacancies.
The term of the members shall be two (2) years, except that the term of the Board of Trustees member shall run the length of his or her term of office or as determined by the Board of Trustees. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any appointed member, a successor shall be appointed by the Board of Trustees to serve the unexpired portion of the term. Upon expiration of their term, members may be reappointed to the Tourism Advisory Board at the discretion of the Board of Trustees. Any member having three (3) consecutive unexcused absences shall automatically be considered to have resigned.
(Ord. 2007-14 §1; Ord. 2009-02 §1)
CHAPTER 2 Administration and Personnel
Page 46
Sec. 2-284. Compensation.
Members of the Tourism Advisory Board shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 2007-14 §1; Ord. 2009-02 §1)
Sec. 2-285. Duties and responsibilities.
The Tourism Advisory Board shall provide guidance in the development of the tourism industry in the community and assist in the implementation of the Town's Marketing and Development Plan by:
1. Continuing the positive relationship between the Town and the business industry;
2. Advising the Town staff and the Board of Trustees concerning the preparation of a budget for the expenditures of funds in the Marketing and Economic Development Fund in order to promote and market the community;
3. Striving to create a viable downtown and provide jobs and income needed to sustain an active and vibrant downtown; and
4. Performing such other and further duties and responsibilities with respect to the Town's marketing and economic development efforts as may, from time to time, be delegated by the Board of Trustees, or which are provided for by Town ordinance.
(Ord. 2007-14 §1; 2009-02 §1)
Sec. 2-286. Operation.
a) The Tourism Advisory Board shall elect officers consisting of a Chairperson, Vice Chairperson and a Secretary. Officers shall serve for a period of one (1) year. They may succeed themselves for not more than two (2) terms. Officers shall be selected at the first meeting of every year. Officers shall perform duties appropriate to their titles, such as:
1. Chairperson: Lead meetings, work with staff on agenda development and coordinate with Town staff on projects and involvement in public relations.
2. Vice Chairperson: Fill in for the Chairperson when necessary and assist as needed with projects and public relations.
3. Secretary: Take and prepare minutes in a timely manner. Copies of all minutes shall be forwarded to the Board of Trustees. Minutes should be reflective of the agendas.
b) Town staff shall provide assistance to the Tourism Advisory Board as needed and at the direction of the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2007-14 §1; Ord. 2009-02 §1)
Sec. 2-287. Meetings.
The Tourism Advisory Board shall meet at a place and time to be determined by a majority of the members of the Tourism Advisory Board.
(Ord. 2007-14 §1; Ord. 2009-02 §1)
Sec. 2-288. Rules and regulations.
The Tourism Advisory Board may adopt rules and regulations governing its operation; provided, however, that no such rule or regulation, or any amendment thereto, shall become effective until such rule, regulation or amendment has been approved by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2007-14 §1; Ord. 2009-02 §1)
Secs. 2-289—2-300. Reserved.

ARTICLE II Funds

Sec. 4-11. General fund created.
There is hereby created a fund, to be known as the General Fund, which shall consist of the following:
1. All cash balances of the Town not specifically belonging to any existing special fund of the Town.
2. All fixed assets of the Town (to be separately designated in an account known as the General Fixed Assets) not specifically belonging to any existing special fund of the Town.
3. Lottery funds received through the State Conservation Trust Fund shall be maintained as a separate revenue stream within the General Fund and shall be used only for the acquisition, operation and maintenance of parkland and/or the municipal swimming pool.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 859 §1 2, 2000)
Sec. 4-12. Utility fund created.
There shall be created a fund to be known as the Utility Fund which shall consist of revenues, expenditures and fixed assets of the water department, sewer department and refuse.
(Ord. 859 §3, 2000)
Sec. 4-13. Capital improvements fund created.
There shall be created a Capital Improvements Fund to which funds shall be appropriated when such funds are available for the implementation of capital projects and the purchase of major equipment. All fixed assets as the result of project completion or equipment purchase -shall be accounted for in the General Fund and transferred thereto at the end of the year.
(Ord. 859 §4, 2000)
CHAPTER 4 Revenue and Finance
Page 48
Sec. 4-14. Custody and management of funds.
Moneys in the funds created in this Chapter shall be in the custody of and managed by the Treasurer. The Treasurer shall maintain accounting records and account for all of said moneys as provided by law. Moneys in the funds of the Town shall be invested or deposited by the Treasurer in accordance with the provisions of law. All income from the assets of any fund shall become a part of the fund from which derived and shall be used for the purpose for which such fund was created; provided that, except as otherwise provided in this Article, by other ordinances or laws or by this Code, the Board of Trustees may transfer out of any fund any amount at any time to be used for such purpose as the Board of Trustees may direct.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 859 §5, 2000)

Sec. 4-51. Purpose.
The purpose of this Article is to impose a sales tax on the sale of tangible personal property at retail and upon the furnishing of certain taxable services in the Town.
(Prior code 3.08.010)
CHAPTER 4 Revenue and Finance
Page 49
Sec. 4-52. Definitions adopted by reference.
For the purpose of this Article, the definitions of words herein contained shall be as defined in Section 39-26-102, C.R.S., and said definitions are incorporated herein by this reference.
(Prior code 3.08.020)
Sec. 4-53. Statutory provisions applicable; adopted by reference.
For the purpose of collection, administration and enforcement of this Article by the Director of Revenue, the provisions of Sections 39-26-114, 39-26-118 and 29-2-106, C.R.S., shall be deemed applicable and incorporated into this Article.
(Prior code 3.08.030)
Sec. 4-54. Exemptions from tax; sale of certain personal property.
a) Sales of personal property on which a specific ownership tax has been paid or is payable shall be exempt from the tax imposed by this Article when such sales meet both of the following conditions:
1. The purchaser is a nonresident of or has its principal place of business outside of the Town; and
2. Such personal property is registered or required to be registered outside the limits of the Town under the laws of this State.
b) Sale of food as defined in Section 39-26-102(4.5), C.R.S., shall be exempt.
c) Sales and purchases of electricity, coal, wood, gas, fuel oil or coke sold, but not for resale, to occupants of residences, whether owned, leased or rented by said occupants, for the purpose of operating residential fixtures and appliances which provide light, heat and power for such residences, shall be exempt. For the purposes of this Subsection (c), gas includes natural, manufactured and liquefied petroleum gas. This Subsection is automatically repealed July 1, 1982, unless the corresponding exemption from the state sales tax, Section 39-26-114(1)(a)(XXI), C.R.S., is extended by the Colorado State Legislature, in which case the exemption granted by this Subsection shall be extended for the same time period for which the corresponding state sales tax exemption is extended.
d) Exemptions:
1. As provided in Section 39-26-114(11), C.R.S., purchase of machinery or machine tools in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) by a person engaged in manufacturing, to be used in the State directly and exclusively by such person in manufacturing tangible personal property for sale or profit, to the extent such purchases do not exceed five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) in each calendar year, shall be exempt.
2. A parent corporation and all closely held subsidiary corporations, as defined in Section 39-26-102(10)(k), C.R.S., shall be considered one (1) person for the purposes of this Subsection (d) and, as a group, shall be subject to the provisions of Subsection (d)(1).
3. As used in this Subsection (d), manufacturing means the operation of producing a new product, article, substance or commodity different from and having a distinctive name, character or use from raw or prepared materials.
4. In order to qualify for the exemption provided in this Subsection (d), a purchase must also qualify for the investment tax credit against federal income tax provided by Section 38 of the "Internal Revenue Code of 1954," as amended.
5. An exemption may not be claimed under this Subsection (d) for sales tax paid in another state which is credited against Colorado sales tax or use tax or both.
6. To receive an exemption under this Subsection (d), a declaration of entitlement must be filed by the purchaser with the vendor of the machinery or machine tools and with the Executive Director of the Department of Revenue.
(Prior code 3.08.060)
Sec. 4-55. Exclusions from amount subject to tax.
The amount subject to tax under this Article shall not include the state sales and use tax imposed by Article 26, Chapter 39, C.R.S.
(Prior code 3.08.110)
CHAPTER 4 Revenue and Finance
Page 50
Sec. 4-56. Gross receipts to include delivery charges.
As used in this Article, the gross receipts from sales shall include delivery charges when such charges are subject to the state sales and use tax imposed by Article 26, Chapter 39, C.R.S., regardless of the places to or from which delivery is made.
(Prior code 3.08.120)
Sec. 4-57. Place where sales consummated; generally.
For the purpose of this Article, all retail sales shall be considered consummated at the place of business of the retailer, unless the tangible personal property sold is delivered by the retailer or his or her agent to a destination outside the limits of the Town or to a common carrier for delivery to a destination outside the limits of the Town.
(Prior code 3.08.130)
Sec. 4-58. Place where sales consummated; retailers with no permanent place of business.
In the event a retailer has no permanent place of business or more than one (1) place of business in the Town, the place or places at which the retail sales are consummated for the purpose of this sales tax shall be determined by the provisions of Article 26, Chapter 39, C.R.S., and by the rules and regulations promulgated by the Department of Revenue.
(Prior code 3.08.140)
Sec. 4-59. Imposition; amount.
There is hereby imposed on all sales of tangible personal property and on the furnishing of taxable services a tax equal to two percent (2%) of the gross receipts. The imposition of the tax on individual sales shall be in accordance with schedules set forth in the rules and regulations promulgated by the Department of Revenue or by separate ordinance of the Town.
(Prior code 3.08.150; Ord. 912 §1, 2004)
Sec. 4-60. Nonapplicability.
For sales or commercial transactions consummated on or after January 1, 1986, the Town's sales tax shall not apply to the sale of construction and building materials as the term is used in Section 29-2-109, C.R.S., if such materials are picked up by the purchaser within the incorporated limits of the Town and if the purchaser of such materials presents to the retailer a building permit or other documentation acceptable to the Town Clerk evidencing that a local use tax has been paid or is required to be paid.
(Prior code 3.08.151)
Sec. 4-61. Credit for sales or use taxes previously paid to another municipality.
For sales or commercial transactions consummated on or after July 1, 2004, the Town's sales tax shall not apply to the sale of tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of services if the transaction was previously subjected to a sales or use tax lawfully imposed on the purchaser or user by another statutory or home rule municipality equal to or in excess of two percent (2%) of the gross receipts realized from the sale or transaction. A credit shall be granted against the Town's sales tax with respect to such transaction equal in amount to the lawfully imposed local sales or use tax previously paid by the purchaser or user to the other statutory or home rule municipality. The amount of the credit shall not exceed one percent (1%) of the gross receipts realized from the sale or transaction.
(Prior code 3.08.152; Ord. 912 §2, 2004)
Sec. 4-62. Property and services taxable.
The tangible personal property and services taxable pursuant to this Article shall be the same as the tangible personal property and services taxable pursuant to Section 39-26-104, C.R.S.
(Prior code 3.08.160)
CHAPTER 4 Revenue and Finance
Page 51
Sec. 4-63. Collection, administration and enforcement.
The collection, administration and enforcement of this sales tax shall be performed by the Director of Revenue in the same manner as the collection, administration and enforcement of the state sales tax. The provisions of Article 26, Chapter 39, C.R.S., and all rules and regulations promulgated by the Director of Revenue shall govern the collection, administration and enforcement of the sales tax imposed by this Article.
(Prior code 3.08.170)
Sec. 4-64. Amendment or change of provisions authorized when.
The Board of Trustees may amend, alter or change this Article, except as to the two percent (2%) rate of tax imposed in this Article, subsequent to adoption by a majority vote of the Board of Trustees. Such amendment, alteration or change need not be submitted to the electors of the Town for their approval.
(Prior code 3.08.180; Ord. 912 §3, 2004))
Sec. 4-65. Collection fee authorized; amount.
It is ordained by the Board of Trustees that all authorized vendors operating within the corporate limits of the Town are authorized to retain three and one-third percent (3 1 / 3 %) of all municipal sales tax collected as a fee for such collection.
(Prior code 3.12.010)
Sec. 4-66. Unlicensed sales or services prohibited.
Any person engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of taxable services in the Town, without having secured a license therefor, except as specifically provided herein, shall be guilty of a violation of this Article.
(Prior code 3.08.210)
Secs. 4-67—4-80. Reserved.
ARTICLE V Disposition of Surplus Property
Sec. 4-81. Identification.
Sec. 4-82. Sale of surplus property.
Sec. 4-83. Report.
Secs. 4-84—4-100. Reserved.
Sec. 4-81. Identification.
Any item of personal property of the Town having a current value of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more may be declared surplus by the Board of Trustees, and other property may be declared surplus by the Town Administrator.
(Ord. 744 §1, 1996)
Sec. 4-82. Sale of surplus property.
a) The Town Administrator may advertise for bid in the official newspaper of the Town and give notice to such persons or entities as he or she deems necessary to reach a representative sample of interested prospective buyers. All bids shall be sealed and shall be opened in public at a designated time and place no sooner than ten (10) days after publication of notice in the newspaper.
b) The Town Administrator may conduct an auction at a designated time and place after first giving at least ten (10) days notice in the official newspaper of the Town and such other notice as he or she deems appropriate. At the auction, surplus property will be sold to the highest responsible bidder for cash, but the Town Administrator may establish minimum sales prices.
c) At an auction or at a bid opening, the Town Administrator may reject all bids and advertise to give notice again for another auction or bid opening. If, at an auction or bid opening, no one offers to purchase an item of personal property, the Town Administrator may donate the item to any person or
CHAPTER 4 Revenue and Finance
Page 52
entity to which donations may lawfully be made or, if the item appears to have little or no value, he or she may dispose of it in any way he or she deems fit.
(Ord. 744 §2, 1996)
Sec. 4-83. Report.
The Town Administrator shall promptly report to the Board of Trustees the manner and terms of all completed dispositions of surplus property.
(Ord. 744 §3, 1996)
Secs. 4-84—4-100. Reserved.
