Sec. 7-41. Definitions.
As used in this Article, the following words shall be construed to have the meanings defined below:
1. Garbage means and consists of every accumulation of animal, vegetable and other matter that attends the preparation, consumption, decay or dealing in or storage of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, foods or vegetables. The term garbage does not include dishwater, wastewater or dead animals.
2. Rubbish means and consists of wood and wood products, branches, chips, shavings, woodenware, dodgers, printed matter papers, pasteboard, grass, rags, straw, rubber products, plastic and all other combustible material not included in this Article under the term garbage.
3. Waste matter means and consists of crockery, queensware, glass, glassware, ashes, cinders, shells, animal waste matter and other noncombustible material, but shall not include noncompressible metal material, soil, sand, gravel, stone and building material.
(Prior code 8.08.010; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 7-42. Containers; required where; construction specifications.
For the purpose of facilitating the removal and disposal of garbage and securing proper sanitary conditions and for regulating the same over the public streets and alleys of this Town, every owner or his or her agent, or occupant of any house, hotel, restaurant, building, flat, apartment, tenement or store within the corporate limits of the Town, where persons reside, board or lodge, or where meat, vegetables or food are sold, kept, prepared or served, shall provide for each house, hotel, restaurant, building, flat apartment, tenement or store at their own expense, and shall at all times maintain in a clean condition and in good order a container or containers for garbage, rubbish and waste.
(Prior code 8.08.020; Ord. 743, 1996)
Sec. 7-43. Containers.
a) Garbage, rubbish and waste matter shall be placed in disposable plastic bags with the top securely tied or in containers of not more than thirty-three (33) gallons capacity except as hereinafter provided. The combined weight of the contents and bag or containers shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds. The container shall be a watertight, solid and durable receptacle and shall be provided with a suitable handle or handles on the outside and with a tightly fitting lid/cover equipped with a handle. The container must not have anything within the container to prevent the free discharge of the contents.
b) Business establishments, including apartments, which have garbage, rubbish or waste matter in quantities sufficient to make impractical its storage in thirty-three (33) gallon containers, shall provide other suitable means of containing such so as to prevent it from being scattered along the streets and
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 121
alleys. Rubbish and waste matter shall be deposited in such a manner as to be readily accessible to the collection crews.
c) All containers that have deteriorated to the extent of having jagged or sharp edges capable of causing injury to the collector or others whose duty it is to handle the containers or to such an extent that the lid shall not fit tightly or securely, will be condemned by the Town acting through the Town Administrator.
d) It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb or scavenge the containers contents referred to in this Section.
e) Extra yard trash such as tree limbs and shrubbery which will not fit in garbage cans shall be cut in lengths not to exceed four (4) feet and tied in bundles. Ashes and cinders shall be placed in noncombustible containers. Total weight of any carton, container or bundle shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds.
(Prior code 8.08.030; Ord. 743, 1996)
Sec. 7-44. Containers; placement for pickup; pickup schedule.
The owner shall cause said receptacles or containers for garbage, rubbish and waste matter to be placed adjacent to the alley nearest the premises so that the same will be readily accessible to the person or persons charged with the duty of removing the same. In residential districts where no alley is adjacent to the premises, any person having rubbish, garbage or waste matter for disposal must place the receptacles or containers provided above at the curb in front of the residence on the day or days of the week specified by the Town as pickup days. It is unlawful to place or store for disposal empty paper cartons or other type of containers or protective transportation material on the outside of any building, unless placed in an approved fenced area or regulation-type garbage and trash disposal container. Removal and disposal of this material shall be weekly at the expense of the owner or operator of the establishment.
(Prior code 8.08.040)
Sec. 7-45. Deposit on private grounds prohibited; protection from vermin and dogs required.
a) It is unlawful to keep, place or deposit garbage, rubbish or waste matter on any private grounds or premises whatsoever, except in cans or receptacles required by the terms of this Article.
b) It is unlawful to have, store, deposit or keep garbage where rats, mice or dogs can have access thereto or feed thereon.
(Prior code 8.08.060)
Sec. 7-46. Disposal by burning prohibited.
Except as provided in Section 7-92(b), it is unlawful to dispose of waste or other combustible material by burning within the corporate limits of the Town.
(Prior code 8.08.070)
Sec. 7-47. Compliance with article required; inspection authorized.
All persons shall at all times comply strictly with the terms and provisions of this Article, and all garbage cans, rubbish and waste matter containers shall at all times be under the inspection and control of the Town Administrator and the police of the Town.
(Prior code 8.08.080)
Sec. 7-48. Collection and removal; board of trustees authority.
a) The Board of Trustees may enter into a nonexclusive contract or agreement with any person for the collection and removal of garbage, rubbish and waste matter throughout the Town or any part thereof, or it may at its discretion make provisions for the collection and removal of garbage, rubbish and waste matter throughout the Town, or a part thereof, by its own employees or agents. The collection of rubbish and waste matter shall not include such rubbish and waste matter developed from new construction or remodeling of any premises; or the collection of accumulations of garbage, rubbish and trash developed from any fruit or vegetable processing or marketing concern during the
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 122
harvesting or processing season. The disposal of such materials shall be the sole responsibility of the owner of the premises.
b) If any person or business desires to cancel the services of the Town as provided by any third party with whom the Town may have contracted, then and in that event the person or business shall notify the Town Clerk, in writing, within ten (10) days before the first day of the next month of his, her or its desire to cancel the service and shall also inform the Town Clerk as to the alternate method of arrangement he, she or it has made for disposing of his, her or its garbage, rubbish and waste matter. The person or business using a private party for his, her or its trash removal shall still be bound by all other parts of the ordinances of the Town concerning or pertaining to trash removal.
(Prior code 8.08.090)
Sec. 7-49. Transport truck specifications.
It is unlawful for any person to remove or carry, or cause to be removed or carried, on or along the streets and alleys of the Town, any garbage or other matter offensive to sight or smell except in watertight trucks having metal beds or boxes, with proper covers, so that the garbage or other matter shall not be offensive. The garbage shall be so loaded that none of it shall fall, drip or spill on the ground; and every such truck shall be kept clean and well painted.
(Prior code 8.08.100; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 7-50. Collection and removal; charges fixed by resolution; billing.
a) It is unlawful to accumulate garbage, rubbish or waste beyond the period of one (1) week or beyond the capacity of containers on the premises.
b) The charges for the collection and removal of garbage and waste matter shall be fixed by resolution by the Board of Trustees.
c) All persons and businesses receiving collection and removal service for garbage, rubbish and other waste matter shall be billed and shall pay said charges monthly along with other municipal utility charges. Such charges shall be collected in the same manner as other municipal utility charges.
d) Nothing in this Article shall be construed as preventing a commercial establishment from hauling its own waste matter or rubbish providing it is properly disposed of in conformity with all town and county regulations, but such commercial establishments shall still be subject to all other provisions of this Article.
e) The Town Administrator shall have the authority to adopt such other regulations concerning collection and disposal, and/or relating to hauling of refuse in or over the streets in the Town, as necessary.
(Prior code 8.08.110; Ord. 743, 1996)
Sec. 7-51. Collection and removal; charges; disposition of collected funds.
All funds collected by the Town Clerk for the collection of garbage, refuse and waste matter shall be credited to a garbage collection account in the utility fund of the Town, the proceeds of which shall be used for the purpose of buying, maintaining and operating equipment and for the payment of persons employed in the removal thereof; provided, however, that if such collection and removal are contracted by the Town to private businesses or corporations, the proceeds of such garbage, refuse and waste matter funds shall be paid to such private collectors in such amounts as shall be stipulated in the agreement with such private collectors.
(Prior code 8.08.120)
Secs. 7-52—7-70. Reserved.
ARTICLE III Explosives and Flammable Substances
Sec. 7-71. Keeping explosives or flammable substances prohibited; exception.
Sec. 7-72. Gasoline; storage tank installation requirements.
Sec. 7-73. Prohibition of parking of certain hazardous product trucks beyond a certain duration; certificate of exemption.
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 123
Sec. 7-71. Keeping explosives or flammable substances prohibited; exception.
It is unlawful for any person, either as principal or agent, to keep or permit to be kept within the corporate limits of the Town any dynamite, gunpowder, nitroglycerine or other highly flammable or explosive substance by whatsoever name known; except that gunpowder may be kept in quantities not to exceed two hundred (200) pounds, but upon the grade floors only.
(Prior code 8.04.010; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 7-72. Gasoline; storage tank installation requirements.
All gasoline storage tanks within the corporate limits of the Town shall be installed in accordance with Environmental Protection Agency regulations.
(Prior code 8.04.030; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 7-73. Prohibition of parking of certain hazardous product trucks beyond a certain duration; certificate of exemption.
It is unlawful for tanker trucks engaged in the process of hauling hazardous products to park within the Town for a duration of more than one (1) hour unless currently engaged in making a delivery without a certificate of exemption. The definition of hazardous products shall reflect Section 8-20-201, C.R.S.: all gasoline, benzine, benzene, naphtha, benzol, kerosene and other volatile and inflammable liquids as well as the products shown in "Hazardous Categories" of Division VI Appendix VI-A of the Uniform Fire Code. The Town Administrator or his or her designee shall have the authority to issue a certificate of exemption in cases where the lawful conduct of business would require such a truck be available for a longer period of time and to inform the Board of Trustees of all exemptions within a reasonable length of time.
(Ord. 839 §1, 2000)
ARTICLE IV Open Burning Regulations
Sec. 7-74. Definitions.
Sec. 7-75. Outdoor burning.
Secs. 7-76—7-90. Reserved.
Sec. 7-74. Definitions.
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:]
1. Bonfire means an outdoor fire utilized for ceremonial purposes which is limited to a solid wood fuel size in diameter and four (4) feet high and conducted by non-profit organizations, religious institutions, school districts, or governments.
2. Fire Official means the Fire Chief or designated authority charged with the administration and the enforcement of Article VIII of the Palisade Municipal Code and/or the most recently adopted version of the International Fire Code (IFC) as a duly authorized designee.
3. Fire pit (non-portable, wood burning), means a depression dug into the ground and/or an enclosure made from stones, masonry, etc., for keeping a fire used for cooking or warmth. Non-portable fire pits are regulated as a recreational fire according to the International Fire Code. A recreational fire shall not be conducted within twenty-five (25) feet of a structure, property line or combustible material.
4. Fire pit (portable, wood burning and/or propane gas) means a commercially built, above ground portable device regulated as a portable outdoor fireplace according to the International Fire Code. (Examples of portable fire pits include but are not limited to commercially purchased metal or stone chimeneas, portable fire tables, fireplaces and burn bowls utilized for outdoor purposes). Portable fire pits and fireplaces shall not be operated within fifteen (15) feet of a structure or combustible material. (See also, Permanent outdoor fire pit or fireplace.)
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 124
5. Household waste means any waste including garbage and trash, derived from households including single and multiple residences, hotels and motels and other places used for temporary or permanent human habitation.
6. Open burning means any manner of burning, typically vegetative material, whether caused, suffered or allowed, not in a device or chamber designed to achieve combustion, where the products of combustion are emitted, directly or indirectly into the open air. Open burning does not include detonation of manufactured explosives. The burning of materials wherein products of combustion are emitted directly into ambient air without passing through a stack or chimney from an enclosed chamber. Open burning does not include road flares, smudge pots and similar devices associated with safety or occupational uses typically considered open flames, recreational fires or portable outdoor fire places. For the purposes of this definition, a chamber shall be regarded as enclosed when, during the time combustion occurs, only apertures, ducts, stacks, flues or chimneys necessary to provide combustion air and permit the escape of exhaust gas are open. Open burning must be conducted at least fifty (50) feet from any structure (including combustible fences), occupied dwelling, workplace or any other place where people congregate, which is on property owned by or under possessory control of, another person.
7. Permanent fire pit or fireplace means a permanent outdoor, wood burning or gas fire pit or fireplace that is constructed of steel, iron, concrete, clay, masonry or other noncombustible material(s). A permanent outdoor fire pit or fireplace is above ground and purchased or constructed in a manner that attaches the component to a deck, patio or ground such that it is not portable. A permanent outdoor fireplace or pit may be open in design or may be equipped with a chimney and/or a hearth. Permanent outdoor fire pits and fireplaces burning gas or wood shall not be operated within five (5) feet of a structure or combustible material unless otherwise approved in accordance with the International Fire Code or International Building Code.
8. Recreational fire means a wood burning outdoor fire, typically in a homemade enclosure constructed of rocks or bricks or other material which the Fire Official deems safe for the purpose. Recreational fires are not portable and burn materials other than rubbish or household waste and the wood being burned is not being contained in incinerator, permanent or portable outdoor fire pit or fireplace, barbeque grill or barbeque pit and has a total fuel area of three (3) feet (914 mm) or less in diameter and two (2) feet (610 mm) or less in height for pleasure, religious, ceremonial, cooking, warmth, or similar purpose (i.e. fire pits as defined herein, fire rings or campfires). Recreational fires shall not be conducted within twenty-five (25) feet of a structure, property line or combustible material. When possible wood burning recreational fires should be used with a screen/spark arrestor to reduce the chance of fire spread.
9. Rubbish means combustible and noncombustible waste materials, including residue from burning of coal, wood, coke, or other combustible materials, paper, rags, cartons, tin cans, mineral matter, glass, dust and discarded refrigerators, and heating, cooking or incinerator type appliances.
10. Salvage operation means any operation to salvage or reclaim any material for use or sale, such as reprocessing of used motor oils, metals, wire, chemicals, shipping containers, or drums, and specifically automobile graveyards and junkyards.
(Ord. 2017-11, §1)
Sec. 7-75. Outdoor burning.
a) Any outdoor burning not expressly allowed, not expressly prohibited or not otherwise specifically addressed under Section 307 of the International Fire Code (IFC) or Section 7-92 of Chapter 7 of Article V of the Palisade Municipal Code shall be conducted and be pursuant to and in accordance with a permit issued by the Palisade Fire Department (PFD) or its designee. Instructions and stipulations of the permit shall be adhered to.
b) Outdoor burning as allowed or prohibited in Section 307 of the International Fire Code is not considered a stationary source for the purposes of applicability of air quality regulations.
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 125
c) Outdoor burning regulations do not extend to indoor burning practices which are subject to the requirements stated in the most recently adopted version of the International Fire Code and/or by Town ordinance.
d) Where conflicts occur between Section 307 of the International Fire Code and this Chapter shall apply, nothing shall preclude the Fire Official designated by the International Fire Code from enforcing regulatory provisions provided in the most recently adopted version of the International Fire Code that are more restrictive in nature than this Chapter.
e) Requirements that are essential for the public safety of an existing or proposed burning activity which are not specifically provided for by this Chapter or the most recently adopted version of the International Fire Code shall be determined by the Town's Fire Official.
f) Prohibited Burning. The following shall not be permitted:
1. The burning of household waste or rubbish is prohibited including, but not limited to:
a. Natural or synthetic rubber products including tires;
b. Waste oil and/or used oil filters and any waste automotive, machine fluid or lubricant, pesticide, herbicide, and/or any other chemical, process fluid or the constituents thereof;
c. Insulated wire;
d. Plastic, including polyvinyl chloride ("PVC") pipe, tubing and connectors;
e. Tar, asphalt, asphalt shingles, or tar paper;
f. Railroad ties;
g. Wood, wood waste, or lumber which has been painted, stained or which has been treated with preservatives containing arsenic, chromium, pentachlorophenol, or creosote;
h. Batteries;
i. Motor vehicle bodies;
j. Pathogenic wastes; and
k. Asbestos or asbestos containing materials;
2. This Section applies to any kind of salvage operation as defined herein. Open burning as part of any salvage operation is prohibited.
a. Restricted Burning. The following are allowed with a permit issued by the Fire Official.
3. Outdoor burning, open burning and ceremonial bonfires are allowed with a permit approved by the Fire Official and when the fires are subject to and in accordance with regulatory, process and safety provisions stated in the permit issued by the Palisade Fire Department or its designee in accordance with Section 7-92 of the Palisade Municipal Code and the most recently adopted version of the International Fire Code.
a. Unrestricted Burning. The following are allowed without a permit.
4. Maintenance of canals, irrigation and drainage ditches owned and/or operated by a drainage district or canal and/or irrigation company or district;
5. Cooking fires;
a. Open-flame cooking devices in the form of LP-gas or charcoal burner grills that are subject to regulatory and safety provisions stated in the most recently adopted version of the International Fire Code; and
b. Solid-wood fueled cooking fires utilized in outdoor kitchens (permanent masonry fireplaces/pizza ovens), barbeque (also BBQ) smoke houses, BBQ smokers and in-ground cooking pits or devices.
6. Propane or natural gas burning permanent and portable fireplaces and fire pits shall be used in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications;
7. Permanent outdoor fire pits and fireplaces burning gas or wood shall not be operated within five (5) feet of a structure or combustible material unless otherwise approved in accordance with the International Residential Code or International Building Code;
8. Portable fire pits and fireplaces burning gas or wood shall not be operated within fifteen (15) feet of a structure of combustible material;
9. Other liquid-fueled or gas-fueled open-flame devices in the form of heaters and decorative devices such as tiki-torches, lanterns, candles or similar items that are subject to regulatory and safety provisions stated in the most recently adopted International Fire Code;
10. Recreational fires as defined herein. Recreational fires shall not be conducted within twenty-five (25) feet of a structure or combustible material. When possible recreational fires should be used with a screen/spark arrestor to reduce the chance of fire spread;
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 126
11. Recreational fires located in developed Town, County or State approved picnic or campground areas contained in portable and non-portable fire pits or fire grates furnished at the picnic or campground area;
12. Burning (flaring) of natural gas at the sewer treatment plant and when performed in conjunction with drilling, completion and work-over operations of oil and gas wells and when the flaring operation of wells is reasonably necessary in the opinion of the well operator to avoid serious hazard safety; and
13. Fire suppression or Palisade Fire Department training operations.
(Ord. 2017-11, §1)
Secs. 7-76—7-90. Reserved.
ARTICLE V Weeds, Brush and Rubbish
Sec. 7-91. Definitions.
Sec. 7-92. Duty of property owners, tenants and/or property managers to remove weeds, brush and rubbish.
Sec. 7-93. Notice to cut and remove.
Sec. 7-94. Cutting, removal by town.
Sec. 7-95. Assessing costs.
Sec. 7-96. Notice of assessment.

Sec. 7-98. Unlawful to violate this article.
Sec. 7-99. Payment of assessment will not avoid fine.
Secs. 7-100—7-110. Reserved.
Sec. 7-91. Definitions.
As used in this Article, the following words shall be construed to have the meanings defined below:
1. Brush means a volunteer growth of bushes and such as is growing out of place in the location where growing, and shall include all cuttings from trees and bushes, also high and rank vegetable growth which may conceal filthy deposits.
2. Rubbish refers to and incorporates as though set forth fully herein the definitions of the terms garbage, rubbish and waste matter as set forth in Section 7-41 of this Code.
3. Weed means an unsightly, useless, troublesome or injurious, herbaceous plant and such plant is out of place at the location where growing, including those noxious plant species designated in Section 1.3 of the Mesa County Noxious Weed List within the Mesa County Noxious Weed Management Plan, and includes all rank vegetable growth which exhales unpleasant or noxious odors and also high and vegetable growth that may conceal filthy deposits.
(Prior code 8.12.010; Ord. 2016-09, §1)
Sec. 7-92. Duty of property owners, tenants and/or property managers to remove weeds, brush and rubbish.
(a) It is the duty of every owner, tenant and/or property manager who owns, resides upon or manages any lots, tracts or parcels of land (hereinafter the "real estate") within the Town, to cut to the ground all weeds and brush and to remove the same, together with all rubbish of all kinds from the real estate, and to keep the real estate free from weeds, including noxious weeds or brush, and rubbish, including the area between the real estate property line and the street or curb adjoining the real estate or to the centerline of any alley adjoining the property line of any real estate. Noxious weeds shall be controlled pursuant to Section 5.0 Best Management Practices for Noxious Weeds in Mesa County contained within the Mesa County Noxious Weed Management Plan.
(b) Any person whose duty it is to cut and remove weeds and brush from any tract or parcel of land within the Town, which is used for agricultural purposes only, may burn the same under the following conditions:
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 127
1. Said burning shall be restricted to the clearing of ditch banks, fence lines and strictly agricultural uses;
2. No burning shall take place within fifty (50) feet of any building or combustible fence; and
3. A burn permit is obtained from the Fire Department.
(Prior code 8.12.020; Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 792 §5, 1998; Ord. 2009-06 §1; Ord. 2010-03 §1; Ord. 2016-09, §2)
Sec. 7-93. Notice to cut and remove.
a) The Town Clerk shall publish annually for one (1) or more times a notice in the official newspaper of the Town, at the proper time, notifying all owners, tenants and/or property managers of real estate, without naming them, that it is their duty to cut the weeds and brush and to remove the same, together with the rubbish, from the real estate, within the time specified in said notice; and that in default of such cutting and removal, the work may be done under orders of the Town Clerk and the cost thereof, together with the penalties provided in this Article, would be charged to their real estate; and that the aforementioned owners, tenants and/or property managers are guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to additional penalties for the violation.
b) Any police officer having jurisdiction may issue a summons and complaint into Municipal Court for a violation of this Article with or without additional notice to the owners, tenants or property managers of the real estate once the time specified in subsection (a) of this Section has been satisfied.
(Prior code 8.12.030; Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 2010-03 §1)
Sec. 7-94. Cutting, removal by town.
In case of failure of any owner, tenant or property manager of real estate to cut and remove the weeds, brush and rubbish in the time specified by the notices as provided for in Section 7-93 above, the Town Clerk may then proceed to have the work done as soon as practicable. Any work performed pursuant to this Article may be performed by employees of the Town or, in the discretion of the Board of Trustees, by contract with one (1) or more independent contractors.
(Prior code 8.12.040; Ord. 2010-03 §1)
Sec. 7-95. Assessing costs.
Upon completion of the work contemplated by the last preceding section, the Town Clerk shall report in writing to the Board of Trustees, which report shall include a statement of the work done and the expense incurred in so doing, so that the Board of Trustees may determine the cost of such work. Such report shall show the cost for each piece of real estate. After considering the report, the Board of Trustees shall proceed to determine and assess the amount properly chargeable against such delinquent owner and against his or her real estate on account of the cutting and removal of such weeds, brush and rubbish, to which assessment shall be added five percent (5%) thereof for the costs of inspection and other incidental costs.
(Prior code 8.12.050)
Sec. 7-96. Notice of assessment.
The Town Clerk, as soon as possible after an assessment is made by the Board of Trustees, shall send by mail, addressed to the owner of the real estate at the reputed post office address of such owner, a notice of such assessment, which notice shall contain a description of the real estate, the name of the owner and the amount of the assessment.
(Prior code 8.12.060)
Sec. 7-97. Collection of assessments.
It shall be the duty of the owner to pay such assessment within twenty (20) days after the mailing of the notice provided for in Section 7-96, and in case of the owner's failure to do so, the owner shall be liable personally for the amount of the assessment and the same shall be a lien upon the owner's real estate from the time of such assessment. In case the owner fails to pay such assessment within twenty (20) days after notice has been mailed to the owner, as provided by this Article, then it shall be the duty of the Town Clerk to certify the amount of the assessment to the County Treasurer, or other officer of the
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 128
County having custody of the tax list, at the time of such certification, to be by him or her placed upon the tax list for the current year and to be collected in the same manner as other taxes are collected, with ten percent (10%) penalty thereon to defray the cost of collection; and all of the laws of the State for the assessment and collection of general taxes, including the laws for the sale of the property for taxes and the redemption thereof, shall apply to and have full effect for the collection of all such assessments.
(Prior code 8.12.070)
Sec. 7-98. Unlawful to violate this article.
It is unlawful for any owner to violate or otherwise to fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of this Article and, upon any conviction, any such owner shall be subject to the provisions of Section 1-82 of this Code.
(Prior code 8.12.080)
Sec. 7-99. Payment of assessment will not avoid fine.
The fact that assessments have been made against property as provided in this Article for cutting and removing weeds, brush and rubbish shall not prevent the owner from being punished by fine or jailing under the general provisions of this Code, but such fine or penalty may be imposed on those found guilty of violating the provisions of this Article in all cases, whether an assessment has or has not been made in accordance with the provisions of this Article.
(Prior code 8.12.090)
Secs. 7-100—7-110. Reserved.
Editor's note— Ord. 2017-11, §2, adopted May 23, 2017, renumbered former Art. IV as Art. V.

Sec. 7-111. Definitions.
When used in this Article, the following words and terms, unless the context indicates a different meaning, shall be interpreted as follows:
1. Animal means any living vertebrate creature, domestic or wild.
2. At large means a domestic or pet animal, excluding cats, off the premises of the owner or keeper and not under the physical control of a responsible person by means of a leash, cord or chain.
3. Cat means any member of the feline species, including cat hybrids.
4. Dog means any member of the canine species, including dog hybrids.
5. Fowl means ducks and chickens.
6. Harboring means the act of keeping and caring for an animal or providing a premises to which the animal returns for food, shelter or care for a period of at least three (3) consecutive days.
7. Immediate control means control of a domestic or pet animal, excluding cats, by the physical presence of the owner or other responsible person within ten (10) feet of such animal, and such person can exercise voice control over the domestic or pet animal.
8. Keeper means a person who has custodial or supervisory authority or control over an animal.
9. Owner means a person who owns, possesses controls, maintains, keeps or harbors an animal or knowingly permits an animal to remain for a minimum of seven (7) days on or about property or premises owned, controlled or occupied by such person. The term owner shall include all owners where ownership of an animal is shared; all owners shall be jointly and severally liable. The owner may be liable even if the animal was in possession of a different keeper at the time of the offense.
10. Pet animal means dogs, cats, rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters, mice, ferrets, birds, reptiles, amphibians and invertebrates, or any species of wild of domestic or hybrid animal sold, transferred or retained for the purpose of being kept as a household pet, except livestock, and includes any other animal specified in Section 35-80-102(10), C.R.S., as that subsection may be amended from time to time. As used herein, livestock includes cattle, horses, mules, burros, sheep, poultry, swine, llama, goats and any other animal, when used for working purposes or raised for food or fiber production on a farm or ranch. Pet animal does not include an animal used for working purposes on a farm or ranch or a working dog.
11. Public place means a place to which the public, or where a substantial number of the public, has access. Public place includes but is not limited to highways, transportation facilities, schools, places of amusement, parks, playgrounds, parking lots and the common areas of public and private buildings and facilities, as well as the sidewalks and gutters along public streets adjacent to private yards and residences.
12. Swine means the domestic hog, Sus scrofa. It does not include Vietnamese Pot bellied pigs.
(Prior code 6.04.005; Ord. 852 §1, 2000; Ord. 2005-02 §1; Ord. 2007-05 §1)
Sec. 7-112. Prohibition of keeping certain livestock within the town limits.
It is prohibited to house, keep or maintain any cattle, horses, swine, sheep, turkeys, geese, roosters or goats in any zoning district.
(Prior code 6.04.010; Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 900 §1, 2003; Ord. 2007-05 §2)
Sec. 7-112.1. Permit required.
No person shall keep fowl within the corporate limits of the Town unless such person has a valid permit to do so. No property shall be permitted for more than six (6) fowl. No fowl shall be allowed to run or fly at large.
(Ord. 2007-05 §2)
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 130
Sec. 7-112.2. Permit application and annual fee.
Applications for a permit under this Article shall be made to the Town Clerk on forms provided therefor. Each permit shall be valid through the end of the calendar year in which it was issued, and no permit shall be issued absent the payment of a nonrefundable fee in an amount established by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2007-05 §2)
Sec. 7-112.3. Permit conditions.
Prior to the issuance of any permit, and at all times thereafter, when fowl are kept within the Town, the owner or keeper thereof shall comply with the following requirements:
1. All enclosures designed for the keeping of fowl shall be secure enclosures.
2. No animal or fowl shall be kept in such a manner as to constitute a public or private nuisance.
3. Upon complaint, either verbal or written, to the Mayor, Town Administrator or Chief of Police, any fowl being kept shall be kept in a secure enclosure located not less than three (3) feet from all property lines of the owner.
(Ord. 2007-05 §2)
Sec. 7-112.4. Prohibition against commercial use.
Nothing contained in this Article shall in any way be deemed to vary or alter the terms of the Land Development Code. No commercial activity or enterprise involving the keeping of animals shall be permitted in those areas zoned as residential under the provisions of the Land Development Code.
(Ord. 2007-05 §2; Ord. 2008-08 §1)
Sec. 7-112.5. Revocation or denial of permits.
a) The Mayor, Town Administrator or Chief of Police may recommend the revocation of any permit upon satisfactory evidence that the permittee is violating, or has violated, any of the conditions set forth in this Article. Upon such recommendation being filed with the Town Clerk, the Town Clerk shall cause written notice thereof to be mailed to the permittee, notifying said permittee that a hearing on such recommendation will be held at a Board of Trustees meeting in not more than twenty (20) days from the date of the mailing of such notice, specifying the time and place of said hearing. If, upon such hearing, the Board of Trustees finds that the permittee has violated conditions provided in this Article for such permit, the Board of Trustees may forthwith revoke said permit, and the permittee shall be allowed ninety-six (96) hours within which to correct the problem or rid the premises of such fowl being kept.
b) Upon the denial of a permit under the provisions of this Article, the Town Clerk shall cause written notice of such denial to be mailed to the applicant, notifying said applicant thereof. An applicant desiring to appeal such denial shall, within twenty (20) days of receipt of notice of such denial, so notify the Town Clerk in writing, requesting a hearing before the Board of Trustees. Upon receipt of such request for hearing, the Town Clerk shall give notice of the hearing to the applicant in the manner provided for in Subsection (a) above for hearings upon revocation. Upon any such hearing of a denial of permit hereunder, the Board of Trustees shall, following such hearing, either direct that such permit be issued or affirm the denial of the permit.
(Ord. 2007-05 §2)
Sec. 7-112.6. Sanitary regulations.
The premises upon which fowl are to be kept shall be maintained in sanitary conditions and shall comply with all sanitary regulations adopted by the Board of Trustees or the County Health Department. Said premises shall be at all reasonable hours subject to inspection by representatives of the Town or the County Health Department. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to allow such inspection.
(Ord. 2007-05 §2)
Sec. 7-113. Dogs or other animals at large prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for the owner of a domestic or pet animal, excluding cats, to permit such animal to be at large within the limits of the Town; and every owner of a domestic or pet animal, excluding cats,
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals

shall confine it to his or her premises when not on a leash and under the immediate control of a competent and responsible attendant. However, in certain posted designated areas within public parks, a domestic or pet animal, excluding cats, need not be on a leash so long as the owner or other responsible person is exercising immediate control of such animal as defined in Section 7-111.
(Prior code 6.04.030; Ord. 2005-02 §2)
Sec. 7-114. Animals prohibited in public buildings.
It is unlawful for any owner, possessor or keeper of any dog or other animal to take the same into any public building. Any dog or other animal used in aid of a handicapped person is exempt from this Section when actually being so used.
(Prior code 6.04.050; Ord. 805 §1, 1999; Ord. 2008-11 §1)
Sec. 7-115. Vicious dogs and animals.
No person shall own, keep, possess or harbor a vicious dog or other animal within the Town. For the purposes of this Article, a vicious dog or other animal means a dog or other animal that unprovokedly bites or attacks human beings or other animals either on public or private property, or in a vicious or terrorizing manner approaches any person in an apparent attitude of attack on the streets, sidewalks or any public ground or place. It shall be the duty of all police officers to take up and impound any dog or other animal that is reasonably considered by the officer to be vicious. In the event a dog or other animal cannot be taken up and caught by the police officer without the police officer exposing himself or herself to danger of personal injury from such dog or other animal, it is lawful for the police officer to forthwith destroy such dog or other animal without notice to the owner, keeper or possessor thereof.
(Prior code 6.04.090)
Sec. 7-116. Barking dogs.
It is unlawful to keep or harbor any dog which by loud, frequent or habitual barking, yelping or howling causes a serious disturbance to others within the Town. The keeping of such a dog is a public nuisance. Any pet owner who is deemed in possession of a public nuisance as described in this section may be ordered to place electronic shocking devices, commonly known as "bark collars" upon the dog in order to abate the nuisance prior to being ordered to remove the dog. If the owner refuses to place the bark collar on the dog, the animal shall be removed from the premises by the Chief of Police or his or her designated representative at the expense of the owner, keeper or custodian.
(Prior code 6.04.110; Ord. 877 §1, 2002)
Sec. 7-116.1. Habitual offender.
Habitual offender means any pet animal owner, keeper or custodian who has pled guilty to or been found guilty of violating any provision of the ordinances pertaining to the control of animals in their care three (3) times within any eighteen month-period.
(Ord. 877 §2, 2002)
Sec. 7-116.2 Penalties for habitual offenders.
Any owner, keeper or custodian of any pet animal who is deemed to be a Habitual Offender under this Section may be ordered to remove the animals from the Town within a reasonable period of time by the Court. If the order is not complied with, the owner, keeper or custodian may be held in contempt of Court. In such case, the Chief of Police, or his or her representative, shall remove the animals at the expense of the owner, keeper or custodian.
(Ord. 877 §3, 2002)
Sec. 7-117. Damage to property.
Any dog owner whose dog, whether or not running at large, destroys, damages or injures any shrubbery, plants, flowers, grass, lawns, fences or anything whatsoever upon any public property or upon any private property when permission of the owner or tenant of the property has not been obtained, is in violation of this Chapter, and the same is a public nuisance.
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 132
(Prior code 6.04.120)
Sec. 7-118. Notice or knowledge of violation not necessary for prosecution of owner or keeper.
For the purpose of prosecution for violations of this Article, it shall not be necessary in order to obtain a conviction to prove notice or knowledge on the part of the owner, possessor or keeper of the dog or other animal in question that such dog or other animal was violating any of the provisions of this Article at the time and place charged, it being the purpose and intent of this Article to impose strict liability upon the owner, possessor or keeper of any dog or other animal for the actions, conduct and condition of such dog or other animal.
(Prior code 6.04.130)
Sec. 7-119. Impoundment; authorized when; recordkeeping required.
It shall be the duty of every police officer to catch and impound any dog not wearing a license tag, or any dog or other animal being or running at large, in an animal retention center to be designated by the Mayor for such purpose. Upon impounding any dog, a record shall be made of the breed, color and sex of such dog, where it was caught and whether licensed.
(Prior code 6.08.010)
Sec. 7-120. Notice to owner; disposal of unclaimed dogs.
When any dog is impounded pursuant to any provision of this Article, the Town shall, if the dog is licensed, attempt to give notice of the impoundment to the owner. If the dog is not licensed, it shall be transported as soon as practicable to be held by the County Department of Animal Regulations and disposed of as prescribed by law and local program policy. If the dog is licensed, it may be held at the Animal Retention Center for up to twenty-four (24) hours and then transported to the County Department of Animal Regulations as though unlicensed.
(Prior code 6.08.020)
Sec. 7-121. Disposal of other animals.
When any animal other than a dog is impounded pursuant to any provision of this Article, it shall be transported as soon as practicable to be held by the County Department of Animal Regulations and disposed of as prescribed by law and local program policy.
(Prior code 6.08.030)
Sec. 7-122. Redemption procedure; fee required.
The owner of any dog impounded at the Animal Retention Center pursuant to any provision of this Article may reclaim such dog upon payment to the Town Clerk or other designated Town employee of the license fee applicable to such dog under Section 7-123 of this Code, if the dog is unlicensed. Also to be paid is a redemption fee equal to that charged by the County Department of Animal Regulations. Any dog or other animal transported to the County Animal Retention Center may be reclaimed in accordance with the rules and regulations of the center.
(Prior code 6.08.040)
Sec. 7-123. License requirements; issuance, fee and period of validity.
The owner of any dog over four (4) months of age which is kept, possessed, harbored or maintained in the Town shall be licensed in accordance with the County Department of Animal Regulations requirements concerning dog licensing. A current county dog license shall be the only such license required in the Town limits.
(Prior code 6.12.010; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 7-124. Tag; removal prohibited.
It is unlawful for any person, other than the owner, to take or remove the collar or license tag from any dog, unless with the consent of the owner; or to have in his or her possession, or on the neck or
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 133
collar of any dog or dogs owned, possessed, harbored or kept by him or her, any license tag or dog collar which is the property of any other person; or to have in his or her possession any dog which is the property of any other person, without the consent of the owner.
(Prior code 6.12.030)
Sec. 7-125. Inoculation required.
It is unlawful to possess, keep, harbor or maintain any dog over the age of four (4) months in the Town, unless such dog has been inoculated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian within the preceding year.
(Prior code 6.16.010)
Sec. 7-126. Confinement of biting animals.
a) The owner of any dog or other animal which has bitten or which is suspected to have bitten any person or which is suspected of having rabies shall immediately notify the Chief of Police or any police officer of such fact.
b) Any dog or other animal which has bitten or which is suspected to have bitten any person or which is believed to have rabies or to have been exposed to rabies shall be confined, upon order of the Chief of Police or any police officer, for a period of ten (10) days for observation. Such dog shall either be confined at the residence of the owner thereof, if such confinement can be accomplished without exposing such dog or other animal to the public, or, at the option of the Chief of Police or any police officer, such dog or other animal shall be transported to the County Department of Animal Regulations or other suitable facility for impoundment, quarantine and other examinations as the Town deems necessary, at the expense of the owner of the dog or other animal. It is unlawful for any owner of such dog or other animal to permit such dog or other animal during confinement to come into contact with the public.
(Prior code 6.16.030)
Sec. 7-127. Payment of expenses and charges.
a) The owner of any dog or other animal which is caught, impounded, transported, confined, quarantined, tested or examined pursuant to any provision of this Article is liable to the Town and shall reimburse the Town for any and all expenses or charges of any nature which are paid or incurred by the Town in connection with the catching, impounding, transportation, confinement, quarantine, testing or examination of such dog or animal; provided, however, that the owner shall not be liable for any costs or expenses for which the Town is reimbursed by some person or entity other than the owner. Such expenses and charges may include, by way of example and not by way of limitation, charges for transportation, boarding costs, veterinary charges, costs of other medical tests and examinations, and impounding fees. The owner shall be liable for such charges regardless of whether he or she reclaims the dog or other animal from the Animal Retention Center or the County Department of Animal Regulations.
b) As soon as practicable after the Town has incurred expenses or charges described in Subsection (a) above for which the owner of a dog or other animal is liable, the Town shall bill the owner for such expenses or charges. Such expenses and charges shall be due and payable within thirty (30) days from the date of such billing.
c) The fact that charges or expenses have been billed to the owner of a dog or other animal as provided in this Article shall not prevent the owner from being punished by fine or jailing under the penalty provisions of this Code, but such fine or penalty may be imposed on those found guilty of violating the provisions of this Article in all cases, whether costs have been billed or paid in accordance with the provisions of this Article.
(Prior code 6.20.020)
Sec. 7-128. Bees.
It is unlawful for any person to keep, harbor or maintain bees for any purpose within the Town limits, except in the legitimate, nonnegligent and legal agricultural practices as stated in C.R.S. Section 35-3.5-101, 102 and 103, C.R.S. amended.
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 134
(Ord. 651 §1, 1991; Ord. 792 §6, 1998)
Sec. 7-129. Household pets.
a) A maximum of three (3) adult (four (4) months or older) dogs and three (3) adult cats (four (4) months or older) shall be allowed per residential household within the Town limits. In no event shall the total number of adult animals exceed six (6).
b) Dogs and cats kept confined in kennels shall be kept no closer than twenty (20) feet from the nearest residential structure on an adjacent property unless written permission for a lesser distance is obtained from the adjacent occupant or property owner. Such permission may be revoked at any time. Upon revocation, the owner of the animals shall have thirty (30) days to move the animals so that compliance is achieved.
c) It is unlawful for any owner to violate or otherwise to fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of this Section and, upon any conviction, any such owner shall be subject to the provisions of Section 1-82 of this Code.
(Ord. 697, 1994)
Sec. 7-130. Cruelty to animals, prohibition of.
It is unlawful to act or omit to act knowingly or with criminal negligence to overdrive, overload, torture, torment, deprive of necessary sustenance, unnecessarily or cruelly beat, needlessly mutilate, needlessly kill, carry or confine in or upon vehicles in a cruel or reckless manner or otherwise mistreat or neglect any animal, including to fail to provide proper food, drink or protection from the weather or to abandon it.
(Ord. 852 §2, 2000)
Sec. 7-131. Pet animal excrement removal.
a) It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper of any pet animal to cause or allow such animal to soil, defile or defecate on any public property or upon any street, sidewalk, public way, play area or common grounds owned jointly by the members of a homeowners' or condominium association, or upon private property other than that of the owner or keeper, unless such owner or keeper immediately removes and disposes of all feces deposited by such animal by the following methods:
1. Collection of the feces by appropriate implement and placement in a paper or plastic bag or other container.
2. Removal of such bag or container to the property of the pet animal keeper or owner and disposition thereafter in a manner as otherwise may be permitted by law.
b) Pet animal excrement shall not be placed in storm sewers or street gutters, but shall be disposed of in a sanitary manner.
c) Dog, cat or other pet animal excrement may be placed in trash containers if contained in a closed plastic bag or other closed, airtight, nonporous container.
d) An accumulation of animal feces on private or public property, which causes an obnoxious odor and/or the accumulation of flies, maggots or other insects, so as to cause or create an unhealthy, unsanitary or offensive living condition, shall be deemed a public nuisance and shall be abated in accordance with this Chapter. An owner or keeper of an animal, as defined in Section 7-111 of this Article, may be charged with a nuisance violation in addition to the violations described in Subsections (a) through (c) above.
(Ord. 2005-02 §3)
Secs. 7-132—7-134. Reserved.

ARTICLE VII Emergency Medical Services

Sec. 7-135. Purpose.
The purpose of this Article is to:
1. Enact formal policies and regulations for licensing and regulating the operation of ambulances;
2. Protect the public by assuring that ambulances operate safely;
3. Protect the public from unsafe and unsanitary operation of ambulances;
4. Allow for adequate emergency ambulance service and nonemergency ambulance services in all areas of the Town; and
5. Allow for the orderly and lawful operation of a local emergency medical services system.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-136. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
1. Advanced Life Support (ALS ) means prehospital medical intervention delivered by paramedics utilizing invasive medical procedures, under protocol and physician direction, for field stabilization of ill or injured patients.
2. Ambulance means a vehicle specially constructed, modified or equipped and used for the purpose of transporting sick, injured, convalescent, infirm or otherwise incapacitated persons. Such term does not include the nonemergency transportation of persons confined to wheelchairs.
3. Ambulance service means the furnishing, operation, conduct as, maintaining, advertising or otherwise engaging in or professing to be engaged in the transportation of patients by ambulance; also including, but not limited to, the person so engaged or professing to be so engaged.
4. Ambulance service permit means written authorization by the Town to an ambulance service to provide ambulance service within the town.
5. Ambulance station means the premises (including living quarters) located within the Town from which the ambulance service provides service.
6. Base hospital means the source of direct medical communications with and responsibility for the supervision of the field emergency care performance by emergency medical technicians, emergency medical technician intermediates and/or paramedics.
7. Basic life support (BLS) means pre-hospital medical intervention delivered by emergency medical technicians, and field patient care providing basic treatment and stabilization of ill or injured patients.
8. Designated dispatch center means the regional communication center of the Town, which is responsible for 911 emergency services telecommunications, and which dispatches emergency personnel and equipment.
9. Emergency call (also referred to as an emergent call ) means a request for an ambulance to transport or assist persons in apparent sudden need of medical attention or in medical emergency, or to transport blood or any therapeutic device, accessory to such device, tissue or organ.
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 136
10. Emergency medical services (EMS) means any actual or self-perceived event which threatens life, limb or well-being of an individual in such a manner that need for immediate medical care is created. Emergency medical services also includes the transportation of a patient, regardless of the presumption of death, or transportation of a body for the purpose of making an anatomical gift.
11. Emergency medical technician intermediate means a certified technician between the level of paramedic and EMT-B. This classification is not to be equated to that of paramedic, nor is it comparable to an EMT-B.
12. Emergency response list means the official list maintained by the designated dispatch center of permittees who possess an emergency ambulance service permit.
13. License means an authorization issued by the Board of County Commissioners to operate an ambulance service, publicly or privately, within the County.
14. Medical services provider means any agency that provides a medical service or medical treatment, at either BLS level or ALS level and/or provides transportation of patients.
15. Nonemergency call (also referred to as nonemergent call ) means calls which require routine medical services in conjunction with transportation, e.g., patient transfer from hospital to nursing home.
16. Physician advisor means a physician (M.D. or D.O.) currently licensed by the State, who established protocols for medical acts performed by emergency medical services personnel and who is specifically designated and responsible to assure the competency of the performance of those acts by EMS personnel, in accordance with applicable rules of the State Board of Medical Examiners.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-137. Exemptions.
a) This Article shall not apply to vehicles operated as ambulances and to persons engaged in ambulance service where ambulance services are rendered at the request of any law enforcement or fire protection agency during any state of war emergency, state emergency or disaster, local emergency or disaster or during any period when the Town determines that adequate emergency ambulance service is not available from existing permittees.
b) This Article shall not prevent any peace officer, firefighter or physician licensed to practice medicine in this State from arranging for the transportation of an individual in need of emergency medical care when no ambulance with an appropriate ambulance service permit is available and such transportation is required immediately for the preservation of life or to avoid substantial impairment of the patient's physical or mental condition.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-138. Standard operating procedures manual.
The Board of Trustees shall adopt by resolution a Standard Operating Procedures manual. The Fire Chief may amend or add to those procedures as may be necessary from time to time to carry out the intent of such standard operating procedures. One (1) certified copy of such manual, with the most recent amendments, shall be filed with the Town Clerk. Additional copies shall be kept in the office of the Fire Chief for review by the general public. Ambulance permittees shall receive one (1) copy of the Standard Operating Procedures Manual. The Standard Operating Procedures Manual shall have the force and effect of law with respect to all ambulance operators, drivers and attendants.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-139. Regulations.
The Fire Chief or his or her designee shall make necessary and reasonable rules and regulations covering ambulance service, ambulance equipment, ambulance personnel and dispatch standards for the effective and reasonable administration of this Article. Prior to adoption, such regulations shall be submitted to the physician advisor for his or her comments and concurrence.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 137
Sec. 7-140. Location of ambulance station; inspection of facilities.
a) Each ambulance service provider shall establish an ambulance station, which is so located as to provide the minimum response time, considering traffic, street patterns and other ambulance station locations. All locations shall be approved by the Fire Chief or his or her designee prior to commencing operations and shall comply with all applicable zoning and building regulations and shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition.
b) Each ambulance station shall be equipped with all communication equipment as required by the Standard Operating Procedures Manual, adopted pursuant to Section 7-138 above.
c) The Fire Chief or his or her designee shall inspect the facilities, equipment and methods of operation of each ambulance service permittee.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-141. Permits.
a) Required. No person (either as owner, agent or otherwise) shall furnish, operate, conduct, maintain or otherwise engage in or advertise, offer or profess to engage in ambulance service unless the person holds (and is entitled to hold) a currently valid ambulance service permit. No permit is required for ambulance services that are transporting patients to or through the Town which do not have their principal service area in the County.
b) Application form. An application for an ambulance service permit shall be made on the form required by the Fire Chief or his or her designee.
c) Application information.
1. Each applicant who desires an ambulance service permit shall submit the following information:
a. The name and address of the applicant, registered owner, partner, officer, director, controlling shareholders if a corporation, sole proprietorship or partnership.
b. The name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business.
c. A description of each ambulance including the make, model, year of manufacture, vehicle identification number and color scheme, insignia and other distinguishing characteristics of the vehicle.
d. A statement that the applicant owns or has under his or her control, in good operating condition, required equipment to consistently provide ambulance service and that the applicant owns or has access to suitable facilities for maintaining his or her equipment in a clean and sanitary condition.
e. A description of the company's program for maintenance of its vehicles.
f. A description of the number and type, frequency and line codes of the vehicles' radios.
g. A description of the locations from which ambulance services will be provided.
h. A list, amended as required during the year for any personnel changes, giving the name and a description of the training for each ambulance attendant and driver, and a copy of each certificate or license held establishing the qualifications of the ambulance personnel.
i. A description of the company's training and orientation programs for all attendants, dispatchers, drivers and the provision for continuing education of the advanced life support personnel.
j. All service charges and rate structures of the company.
k. The number of advanced life support units deployed on each shift.
2. Evidence of insurance coverage as required by the State and this Article.
3. The applicant may be required to submit such other information as the Fire Chief or his or her designee deems necessary for compliance with this Article.
a. Application investigation. Upon receipt of a completed application and the required fee, the Fire Chief or his or her designee shall make or cause to be made an investigation to determine if:
4. The applicant meets the requirements of this Article and other applicable laws and regulations; and
5. That the radio equipment listed by the applicant is in good working order and is integrated with the existing communications system.
d) Issuance. Within ninety (90) days of receipt of an application for an ambulance service permit, the Fire Chief or his or her designee shall make a determination as to whether the applicant meets all
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 138
requirements of this Article and whether the public health, safety and welfare require the granting of the permit. In making such determination, the Fire Chief or his or her designee shall consider, among other things, the demand and necessity for ambulance service, whether the applicant is able to provide service, whether the applicant has knowingly made false statements of fact in his application and whether, under this Article, the applicant was previously a holder of a permit issued which has been revoked or not renewed based on violations of the law, this Article or otherwise.
e) Denial. If it is determined that the applicant for an ambulance service permit does not meet all requirements of this Article, then the Fire Chief or his or her designee shall deny the application and notify the applicant in writing within ninety (90) days of receipt of the application.
f) Appeal from denial of issuance. Whenever the Fire Chief or his or her designee denies an application for an ambulance service permit, the applicant may request a hearing before the Board of Trustees at which the applicant will have the opportunity to appeal the decision of denial. The appeal hearing shall be scheduled within thirty (30) days of the applicant's written request for such hearing. Following a denial the applicant must wait one (1) year before reapplying.
g) Finality of decision. The decision of the Fire Chief or his or her designee rendered pursuant to the application process under this or her Article shall be final unless appealed to the Board of Trustees within thirty (30) days after a decision is rendered in writing and notice is given to an applicant by certified mail.
h) Term. Permits under this Article shall be continued upon payment of the annual renewal fee unless earlier suspended, revoked or terminated.
i) Existing ambulance service application. Within 60 days of the effective date of this Article, the ambulance companies that have been continuously operating for a minimum of one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the effective date of this Article may apply for and obtain an ambulance service permit. The Fire Chief or his or her designee shall issue or deny a permit to each existing company within sixty (60) days of receipt of an application for such permit based upon their ability to meet the requirements as set forth in this Article. The fee for the initial permit for existing companies shall be the fee set for new applicants.
j) Changes of information. The applicant and/or permittee under this article shall report to the Fire Chief or his or her designee any change in the information required in Subsection (c) of this Section within ten (10) days of the effective date of the change.
k) Transfer of permit. No ambulance service permit shall be transferred to another person except upon prior approval of the Fire Chief or his or her designee. Application for transfer of any such permit shall be subject to the same terms, conditions and requirements as if the application were for a new permit.
l) Renewal of permit. Permittees under this Article shall annually file an application for permit renewal on a form furnished by the Fire Chief or his or her designee, which form shall include the information required by Subsection (c) of this Section. The renewal application shall be accompanied by a renewal fee.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-142. Fees.
The Board of Trustees shall set all ambulance service fees by resolution. The fees shall not exceed the reasonable cost of administering this Article and providing for the orderly provision of emergency medical services.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-143. Personnel and equipment standards.
a) Any ambulance driver utilized by a permittee shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age, shall be trained and competent in the proper use of all emergency ambulance equipment, shall hold current certification as an emergency medical technician B and shall demonstrate compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.
b) The permittee shall provide a minimum of one (1) paramedic, trained and competent in current ALS paramedic techniques for ALS equipped ambulances. Each permittee shall provide a minimum of one (1) ALS staffed and equipped ambulance and one ALS equipped ambulance, twenty-four (24) hours per day. Each permittee shall provide and operate a minimum of one (1) backup ambulance. The
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 139
backup ambulance shall be ALS equipped and shall respond in the event of mechanical failure of the primary ALS unit.
c) Every ambulance driver, attendant, EMT or paramedic utilized by a permittee shall hold a certificate from the State or an otherwise accredited training program indicating successful completion of their respective training.
d) Each person providing ambulance service subject to a permit under this Article shall staff each ambulance with required minimum personnel who shall wear clean uniforms, be neat and comply with the standard operating procedure requirements of this Article.
e) Each permittee providing ambulance service under this Article shall provide and maintain, at its own expense, a communication system meeting the requirements of the Fire Chief or his or her designee and the Standard Operating Procedures Manual promulgated under this Article.
f) Each permittee providing ambulance service under this Article shall assign at least one (1) person to be responsible for receiving calls and dispatching ambulances for nonemergency calls. Permittee shall provide such services on a twenty-four (24) hour basis and shall train the dispatcher in accordance with a curriculum developed by the Fire Chief or his or her designee so as to be able to operate radios and handle calls according to established protocols.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-144. Vehicle inspections
a) Every ambulance shall be authorized and inspected by the Fire Chief or his or her designee and shall meet the requirements of this Article and all other applicable city, county and state laws, rules and regulations.
b) The ambulance service permittee shall allow the Fire Chief or his or her designee to inspect, on a preannounced or unannounced basis, all ambulances used to provide ambulance service. The inspections should be held whenever possible during normal business hours. The purpose of such inspections may include, but shall not be limited to, determining if:
1. The ambulances are properly maintained and equipped for the provision of ambulance service pursuant to standard operating procedures.
2. The description of the ambulances required in Section 4-141 of this code is accurate.
3. The ambulances contain radios that are in good working order and that the radios are of correct and compatible frequencies with the emergency medical communications system in accordance with the Standard Operating Procedures Manual.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-145. Response to calls.
a) No ambulance service permittee under this Article shall cause or allow its ambulances to respond to a location without first receiving a specific request for such service at that location. Ambulance service permittees shall cooperate with the Fire Chief or his or her designee in any investigations of possible violations of this section and shall make all logs and records available for inspection and copying at reasonable times at the permittee's place of business.
b) When responding to a dispatched emergency call, the ambulance service provider shall comply with the request of the patient for a desired hospital or the request of the on-scene paramedic, if trauma protocols apply, regarding transportation of the injured or ill party.
c) The ambulance service provider's response to private calls must be consistent with the medical condition or injury of the patient.
d) The ambulance service providers should be aware that not all EMS scenes are without danger of some type. The provider shall use prudent judgment in determining the safety of the scene if it is the first responding unit. The provider is under no obligation, and no obligation is created by the terms of this Article or the operating procedures promulgated under this Article, to enter a scene that is determined to be unreasonably dangerous. The provider agrees to stand by, at a safe distance, until such scene has been secured by another agency.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 140
Sec. 7-146. Permit suspension or revocation.
a) The Fire Chief or his or her designee may suspend or revoke an ambulance service permit for failure to comply and maintain compliance with, or for violation of, any applicable provisions, standards or requirements of state law or this Article or of any regulations promulgated under this Article. The Fire Chief or his or her designee may suspend or revoke a permit if the permittee fails to make and retain records showing its nonemergent/private call dispatches, or if the permittee accepts an emergency call when it is either unable or unwilling to provide the requested service, or fails to inform the person requesting service of any delay and fails to obtain the consent of such person before causing an ambulance to respond from a location more distant than the one (1) to which the request for service was directed. Suspension is not a condition precedent to revocation.
b) Before suspension or revocation of an ambulance service permit, the Fire Chief or his or her designee shall give written notice by United States mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested, to the permittee specifying why such action is contemplated and giving the permittee a reasonable time, not less than seven (7) days or more than thirty (30) days, to comply with the provisions in question or to show cause against suspension or revocation and setting a hearing thereon.
c) At the hearing conducted pursuant to this Article, the Fire Chief or his or her designee has the burden of proof and may present evidence as to why action should be taken and to answer the evidence presented by the permittee.
d) The Fire Chief may reduce the period of time for compliance under a suspension or revocation notice to no less than twenty-four (24) hours and set the matter for hearing immediately upon expiration of such twenty-four (24) hours when the Fire Chief or his or her designee makes written preliminary findings that such action is necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare. When, as a result of such an emergency proceeding, a permit is suspended or revoked, the permittee will have the burden of establishing renewed compliance justifying reinstatement of the permit. Such additional .hearing will be commenced within five (5) days of the permittee's request. The request for or the scheduling of an additional hearing shall not stay the operation of the suspension or revocation order.
e) In hearings conducted pursuant to this Article, evidence must be relevant, noncumulative and of such nature as to be reliable. As far as practicable, the hearing shall be controlled by the Colorado Rules of Evidence and the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure.
f) Hearings conducted pursuant to this Article shall be conducted before a hearing officer designated by the Town Administrator. The hearing officer may issue subpoenas for the production of documents or the attendance of witnesses. The hearing officer shall keep a record of the proceedings either by electronic or stenographic means. At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall promptly prepare a written summary of the evidence and findings and conclusions for consideration by the fire chief or his or her designee. The parties shall equally bear the expenses of the hearing officer and the cost of the hearing. Each party shall bear its own expenses and costs.
g) The hearing officer shall issue a written decision within thirty (30) days of the conclusion of the hearing conducted under this Article. Following a suspension or revocation of an ambulance service permit, the permittee must wait two (2) years before reapplying for a permit.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-147. Permit renewal requirements.
Renewal of an ambulance service permit shall require conformance with all requirements of this Article as upon issuance of an initial permit. Nothing in this Section or otherwise contained in this Article shall be construed as requiring the granting of a permit upon expiration of a previous permit, and the burden of proof respecting compliance with all the requirements of entitlement to a permit shall remain at all times with the applicant for renewal.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-148. Advertisements or offers of service restricted.
No ambulance service permittee under this Article shall announce, advertise, offer or in any way claim that it provides emergency ambulance service unless it possesses a current and valid ambulance service permit and is staffed and provides paramedic service level care for emergency response calls.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
CHAPTER 7 Health, Sanitation and Animals
Page 141
Sec. 7-149. Liability insurance required.
The ambulance service permittee shall obtain and keep in force during the term of such ambulance service permit, comprehensive automobile liability insurance and professional liability insurance issued by a company licensed to do business in the State, insuring the owner against loss by reason of injury or damage that may result to persons or property from negligent operation or defective construction of such ambulance or damage that may result to persons or property from violation of this Article or any other law of the State or of the United States. The comprehensive liability policy shall be in the sum of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for combined single limit bodily injury and property damage. Worker's compensation insurance shall be carried covering all employees of the permit holder. Before a permit is issued, copies of policies or certificates evidencing such policies shall be filed with the Fire Chief or his or her designee. All policies shall contain a provision requiring thirty (30) day notice to be given to the Fire Chief or his or her designee prior to cancellation, modification or reduction in the limits of coverage. Required policies of insurance shall contain an endorsement naming the Town as an additional insured. The required policy of insurance shall provide that the Town is indemnified, defended and held harmless from and against all costs, expenses and liability arising out of, or based upon, any and all property damage or damages for personal injury, including death, which results or is claimed to have resulted from any act or omission on the part of the ambulance service provider or the ambulance service provider's agents or employees.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
Sec. 7-150. Notice of pending legal action, unpaid judgment or liens against service provider.
An ambulance service provider shall provide the Fire Chief or his or her designee with any information in reference to any pending legal action or judgment, unpaid judgment or liens against the ambulance service provider and notice of the transactions or acts giving rise to such legal action, judgment or liens. The ambulance service provider shall notify the Fire Chief or his or her designee in writing of such legal action, judgment or liens within one (1) week of the date served or notified. The information will be reviewed by the Fire Chief or his or her designee, who will make a determination regarding the effect, if any, on the ambulance service provider's ability to provide service in accordance with the requirements of this Article.
(Ord. 747, 1996)
