Sec. 10-241. Possession or use of marijuana by underage person prohibited.
a) Definitions. As used in this Section:
First offense means that the subject person has not had a previous conviction, adjudication, deferred prosecution or deferred judgment for a violation of this Section or comparable law in another jurisdiction.
Marijuana shall have the same meaning as defined in Section 16(2)(f) of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution.
Open and public has the same meaning as set forth in Section 10-243 below.
Second or subsequent offense means any offense after the person is convicted of a first offense.
b) Penalties.
1) Except as described by Section 18-1-711, C.R.S. and subsections (c) and (d) of this Section, a person under twenty-one (21) years of age who possesses, uses, or openly and publicly displays marijuana anywhere within the Town of Palisade for a first offense commits a non-criminal municipal offense and shall be subject to a fine up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) and any treatment program or other conditions ordered by the Municipal Court.
2) Except as described by Section 18-1-711, C.R.S. and subsections (c) and (d) of this Section, a person under twenty-one (21) years of age who possesses, uses, or openly and publicly displays marijuana anywhere within the Town of Palisade commits for a second offense or subsequent offense a criminal municipal offense punishable by up to a three-hundred-dollar fine, up to ninety (90) days incarceration or by both such fine and jail sentence.
3) Except as described by Section 18-1-711, C.R.S., and Subsections (c) and (d) below, a person under twenty-one (21) years of age who possesses, uses or openly and publicly displays marijuana anywhere within the Town commits, for a second offense or subsequent offense, a municipal offense punishable by a fine of up to three hundred dollars ($300.00) or up to ninety (90) days' incarceration, or by both such fine and jail sentence.
c) The possession or use of marijuana shall not constitute a violation of this Section if such possession or use:
1) Takes place for religious purposes protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution; or
2) Is lawful under Article 43.3 of Title 12, C.R.S.
CHAPTER 10 General Offenses
Page 219
d) An underage person shall be immune from criminal prosecution under this Section if he or she establishes the following:
1) The underage person, or another underage person with the underage person, called 911 and reported in good faith that another underage person was in need of medical assistance due to marijuana consumption;
2) The underage person who called 911 provided his or her name to the 911 operator;
3) The underage person was the first person to make the 911 report; and
4) The underage person remained on the scene with the underage person in need of medical assistance until assistance arrived and cooperated with medical technicians or law enforcement personnel on the scene.
e) Prima facie evidence of a violation of Subsection (b) of this Section shall consist of:
1) Evidence that the defendant was under twenty-one (21) years of age and possessed or used marijuana anywhere within the Town; or
2) Evidence that the defendant was under twenty-one (21) years of age and manifested any of the characteristics commonly associated with marijuana intoxication or impairment when present anywhere within the Town.
f) During any trial for a violation of Subsection (a) of this Section, any container with labeling indicating the contents of the container is admissible into evidence, and the information contained on the label on the container is admissible into evidence and is not hearsay. A jury or a judge, whichever is appropriate, may consider the information upon the label in determining whether the contents of the container were composed in whole or in part of marijuana.
g) Nothing in this Section shall be construed to limit or preclude prosecution for any offense pursuant to Article 43.3 or 43.4 of Title 12, C.R.S., except as provided in such Articles.
h) Upon the expiration of one (1) year from the date of a conviction, dismissal, completion of a deferred judgment or conclusion of a deferred prosecution for a violation of Subsection (b) of this Section, the defendant may petition the Municipal Court for an order sealing the record of such Court action. The Court shall grant such petition if the petitioner has not been arrested for, charged with or convicted of any felony, misdemeanor, petty offense or municipal offense during the one-year period described above.
i) relevant jurisdiction shall be admissible at the trial of any person charged with a violation of Subsection (b) of this Section, upon showing that the device or devices used to conduct such test or tests have been approved as accurate in detecting drugs by the Executive Director of the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment.
j) In any judicial proceeding concerning a charge under Subsection (b) of this Section, the Court shall take judicial notice of methods of testing a person's blood or urine for the presence of marijuana and of the design and operation of devices certified by the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment for testing a person's blood or urine for the presence of marijuana. This Subsection does not prevent the necessity of establishing during a trial that the testing devices were working properly and that such testing devices were properly operated. Nothing in this Subsection precludes a defendant from offering evidence concerning the accuracy of testing devices.
(Ord. 06 §2, 2013; Ord. 2014-03, §§1, 2)
Sec. 10-242. Possession of marijuana by person twenty-one years of age and over.
a) It is unlawful for any person twenty-one (21) years of age and over to knowingly possess more than one (1) ounce of marijuana as defined in Section 16(2)(f) of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution. A person who possesses not more than two (2) ounces of marijuana commits a non-criminal municipal offense and shall be punished by a fine of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00). A person who possesses more than two (2) ounces of marijuana but not more than six (6) ounces of marijuana commits a criminal municipal offense punishable by up to a three hundred-dollar ($300.00) fine, up to ninety (90) days incarceration, or by both such fine and jail sentence.
b) During any trial for a violation of Subsection (a) of this Section, any container with labeling indicating the contents of the container is admissible into evidence, and the information contained on the label on the container is admissible into evidence and is not hearsay. A jury or a judge, whichever is appropriate, may consider the information upon the label in determining whether the contents of the container were composed in whole or in part of marijuana.
CHAPTER 10 General Offenses
Page 220
c) Nothing in this Section shall be construed to limit or preclude prosecution for any offense pursuant to Article 43.3 or 43.4 of Title 12, C.R.S., except as provided in such Articles.
d) The qualitative result of a drug test or tests performed by or on behalf of a law enforcement agency with relevant jurisdiction shall be admissible at the trial of any person charged with a violation of Subsection (a) of this Section, upon a showing that the device or devices used to conduct such test or tests have been approved as accurate in detecting drugs by the Executive Director of the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment.
(Ord. 06 §2, 2013; Ord. 2014-03, §3)
Sec. 10-243. Open and public use of marijuana prohibited.
a) Except as described in Section 18-1-711, C.R.S., a person who openly and publicly displays, consumes, or uses two (2) ounces or less of marijuana, as defined in Section 16(2)(f) of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution, commits a non-criminal municipal offense and upon conviction thereof, shall punished by a fine of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) and up to twenty-four (24) hours of useful public service. The open and public display, consumption, or use of more than two (2) ounces of marijuana or any amount of marijuana concentrate shall be deemed possession thereof and a violation shall be punished as provided for in this Chapter or in the Colorado Revised Statutes.
b) As used in this Section, open and public means a place open to the general public which includes a place to which the public or a substantial number of the public has access without restriction, including but not limited to streets, highways, public sidewalks, transportation facilities including rest areas, places of amusement, parks, playgrounds, Town-owned open space, common open space owned by owners' associations, common areas of public buildings and facilities that are generally open or accessible to members of the public without restriction, parking lots and areas and shopping centers or shopping areas.
c) As used in this Section, openly means not protected from unaided observation lawfully made from outside the perimeter of the subject building or property not involving physical intrusion.
d) As used in this Section, publicly means an area that is open to general access with some restrictions and includes marijuana social clubs.
(Ord. 06, 2013; Ord. 2014-03, §4)
Sec. 10-244. Transfer of marijuana prohibited.
Any person who knowingly transfers or dispenses more than one (1) ounce, but not more than two (2) ounces of marijuana, as defined in Section 16(2)(f) of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution, from one person to another for no consideration commits a non-criminal municipal offense and shall not be deemed dispensing or the sale thereof which shall be punishable by a fine up to one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 06 §2, 2013; Ord. 2014-03, §5)
Sec. 10-245. Consumption of marijuana and open marijuana containers in motor vehicles prohibited.
a) As used in this Section, unless the context otherwise requires:
Marijuana shall have the same meaning as defined in Section 16(2)(f) of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution.
Motor vehicle means a vehicle driven or drawn by mechanical power and manufactured primarily for use on public streets and highways, but does not include a vehicle operated exclusively on rails.
Open marijuana container means a receptacle or marijuana accessory that contains any amount of marijuana and:
1) That is open or has a broken seal;
2) The contents of which are partially removed; or
3) There is evidence that marijuana has been consumed within the motor vehicle.
Passenger area means the area designed to seat the driver and passengers, including seating behind the driver, while a motor vehicle is in operation and any area that is readily accessible to the driver or a passenger while in his or her seating position, including but not limited to the glove compartment.
CHAPTER 10 General Offenses
Page 221
4) Except as otherwise permitted in Subsection (c) below, a person, while in the passenger area of a motor vehicle that is on a public street, highway or the right-of-way of a public street or highway within the Town, shall not knowingly:
a. Use or consume marijuana; or
b. Have in his or her possession an open marijuana container.
c. Any person who violates the provisions of this subsection (b) commits a Traffic Infraction and shall be punished by a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00).
d. The provisions of Subsection (b) above shall not apply to:
1. Passengers, other than the driver or a front seat passenger, located in the passenger area of a motor vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for the transportation of persons for compensation;
2. The possession by a passenger, other than the driver or a front seat passenger, of an open marijuana container in the living quarters of a house coach, house trailer, camper, motor home (as defined in Section 42-1-102(57), C.R.S.) or trailer coach (as defined in Section 42-1-102(106)(a), C.R.S.);
3. Possession of an open marijuana container in the area behind the last upright seat of a motor vehicle that is not equipped with a trunk; or
4. The possession of an open marijuana container in an area not normally occupied by the driver or a passenger in a motor vehicle that is not equipped with a trunk.
b) Any person who violates the provisions of Subsection (b) above commits a noncriminal municipal offense and shall be punished by a fine of three hundred dollars ($300.00).
(Ord. 06 §2, 2013; Ord. 2014-03, §6)
Sec. 10-246. Possession of drug paraphernalia prohibited.
a) Drug paraphernalia means all equipment, products and materials of any kind which are used, intended for use or designed for use in planting, propagation, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injection, ingestion, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance in violation of the laws of the State. Drug paraphernalia includes, but is not limited to:
1) Testing equipment used, intended for use or designed for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of controlled substances under circumstances in violation of the laws of the State;
2) Scales and balances used, intended for use or designed for use in weighing or measuring controlled substances;
3) Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from or in otherwise cleaning or refining marijuana;
4) Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons and mixing devices used, intended for use or designed for use in compounding controlled substances;
5) Capsules, balloons, envelopes or other containers used, intended for use or designed for use in packaging small quantities of controlled substances;
6) Containers and other objects used, intended for use or designed for use in storing or concealing controlled substances; or
7) Objects used, intended for use or designed for use in ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing marijuana, cocaine, hashish or hashish oil into the human body, such as:
a. Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads or punctured metal bowls;
b. Water pipes;
c. Carburetor tubes and devices;
d. Smoking and carburetor masks;
e. Roach clips, meaning objects used to hold burning material, such as a marijuana cigarette that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand;
f. Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials;
g. Chamber pipes;
h. Carburetor pipes;
CHAPTER 10 General Offenses
Page 222
i. Electric pipes;
j. Air-driven pipes;
k. Chillums;
l. Bongs; or
m. Ice pipes or chillers.
b) Drug paraphernalia does not include any marijuana accessories as defined in Section 16(2)(g) of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution if possessed or used by a person age twenty-one (21) years or older.
c) In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, the Court, in its discretion, may consider, in addition to all other relevant factors, the following:
1) Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object concerning its use;
2) The proximity of the object to controlled substances;
3) The existence of any residue of controlled substances;
4) Direct or circumstantial evidence of the knowledge of an owner or of anyone in control of the object, or evidence that such person reasonably should know, that it will be delivered to persons who he or she knows, or reasonably should know, could use the object to facilitate a violation of this Section or other applicable law;
5) Instructions, oral or written, provided with the object concerning its use;
6) Descriptive materials accompanying the object which explain or depict its use;
7) National or local advertising on its use;
8) The manner in which the object is displayed for sale;
9) Whether the owner, or anyone in control of the object, is a supplier of like or related items to the community for legal purposes, such as an authorized distributor or dealer of tobacco products;
10) The existence and scope of legal uses for the object in the community; and
11) Expert testimony concerning its use.
d) Any person who commits possession of drug paraphernalia commits a non-criminal municipal offense and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 06 §2, 2013; Ord. 2014-03, §7)
Sec. 10-247. Unlawful cultivation of marijuana on residential property.
a) Definitions. As used in this Section, unless the context otherwise requires:
Enclosed means a permanent or semi-permanent area covered and surrounded on all sides. Temporary opening of windows or doors or temporary removal of wall or ceiling panels for a continuous period of less than seventy-two (72) hours does not convert the area into an unenclosed space.
Locked area means secured at all points of ingress or egress with a locking mechanism designed to limit access such as with a key or combination lock.
Medical marijuana means marijuana that is grown for a purpose authorized by Section 14 of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution.
Primary residence means the place that a person, by custom and practice, makes his or her principal domicile and address to which the person intends to return, following any temporary absence, such as a vacation. Residence is evidenced by actual daily physical presence, use and occupancy of the primary residence and the use of the residential address for domestic purposes, such as, but not limited to, slumber, preparation of or partaking in meals, vehicle and voter registration, or credit, water and utility billing. A person may only have one (1) primary residence.
Retail marijuana or recreational marijuana means marijuana as defined in Section 16(2)(f) of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution.
Secure area means an area within the primary residence or an area on the residence property accessible only to the person possessing, growing or processing the marijuana plants. Secured areas shall be locked or partitioned off to prevent access by children, visitors or anyone not authorized to possess marijuana.
b) Any person who knowingly cultivates medical marijuana or recreational marijuana for personal use in a manner contrary to the requirements of this Section commits a municipal offense and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of up to three hundred dollars ($300.00) or by incarceration for up to ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and incarceration.
CHAPTER 10 General Offenses
Page 223
c) No more than twelve (12) medical or twelve (12) recreational marijuana plants for personal use shall be cultivated on a residential property in any zone district, including but not limited to the Low Density (LDR), Medium Density (MDR), High Density (HDR), Mixed Use (MU), Town Center (TC), Commercial Business (CB), Agricultural Forestry Transitional (AFT) and the Light Industrial (LI) Zone Districts. Cultivation of medical marijuana or recreational marijuana on or in a dwelling unit or property that is not a primary residence is prohibited.
d) The cultivation, production or possession of marijuana plants shall be limited to the following space limitations within a residential unit:
1) Within a single family dwelling unit (Group R-3 as defined by the International Building Code, as adopted in Chapter 22, Section 131); a defined, contiguous secure area not exceeding one hundred fifty (150) square feet within the primary residence of the person cultivating the marijuana.
2) Within a multi-family dwelling unit (Group R-2 as defined by the International Building Code, as adopted in Chapter 22, Section 131); a, defined, contiguous secure area not exceeding one hundred (100) square feet within the primary residence of the person cultivating the marijuana.
3) Marijuana plants shall not be grown in the common area of a multi-family residential structure and shall not be grown or processed in the common areas of a planned community or attached residential development.
e) The cultivation, growing or processing of marijuana plants may occur in enclosed accessory structures such as a shed, garage or greenhouse located on the primary residence property if such structure contains rigid walls and is a locked space to prevent access by children, visitors or intruders.
f) The possession, growing and processing of marijuana plants must not be observable from the exterior of the primary residence or accessory structure, including but not limited to:
1) Common visual observation;
2) Unusual odors, smells, fragrances, or other olfactory stimulus; and
3) Light pollution, glare or brightness that disturbs others.
g) In accordance with Section 9-7-113, C.R.S., the use of a compressed flammable gas as a solvent in the extraction of THC, CBD or other cannabinoids is strictly prohibited.
(Ord. 2017-35, §1)
Secs. 10-248—10-260. Reserved.

Sec. 11-1. Maintenance in clean and snow-free condition required.
Every owner or occupant of any lot, block or parcel of real property within the Town which fronts upon, lies alongside or is adjacent to a sidewalk, shall keep such sidewalk clear of mud, dirt, rubbish, filth and all other obstructions. Every such person shall also be required to remove snow and ice from such sidewalks within twenty-four (24) hours after the cessation of any fall of snow or sleet or after the accretion of any ice; provided, however, that no snow shall be allowed to accumulate to a depth of three (3) inches or more above the sidewalk at any one (1) time within any twelve-hour period of time.
(Prior code 12.04.010)
Sec. 11-2. Reserved.
Sec. 11-3. Fences, walls and vegetation prohibited where.
With the exception of walls and fences, as established in the Land Development Code, no shrub, plant or any other item shall be erected or grown within eighteen (18) inches of the property side of any sidewalk located upon public property, and no trees planted or grown within eight (8) feet of the curb. Nothing in this Section shall amend the setback requirements for fences, walls and other structures stated in the Land Development Code.
(Prior code 12.04.030; Ord. 892 §2, 2003; Ord. 2007-06 §1; Ord. 2008-08 §1)
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 226
Sec. 11-4. Trees; trimming requirements.
All trees standing on any private property in the Town shall be kept trimmed by the owner or occupant of the property so that the branches of such trees and plants projecting over any roadway or alley shall be not less than eleven (11) feet from the ground. All such trees standing on any property in the Town shall be kept trimmed by the owner or occupant of the property so that the branches of such trees and plant[s] projecting over any public sidewalk or private driveway shall be not less than nine (9) feet from the ground.
(Prior code 12.04.040; Ord. 2009-08 §1; Ord. 2016-11, §1)
Sec. 11-5. Width and thickness.
a) Any sidewalk constructed after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Article upon the dedicated streets within the residential district of the Town shall be the curb type, four (4) feet in width, to a thickness of four (4) inches on all regular walks and to a thickness of six (6) inches on all driveways, with a grade from the property side of the sidewalk of one and one-half (1½) inches.
b) Sidewalks in front of and adjacent to business buildings shall conform in width with adjacent sidewalks unless otherwise specified by the Building Inspector.
(Prior code 12.04.050)
Sec. 11-6. Subgrade preparation.
a) (The subgrade upon which sidewalk is to rest shall be prepared by excavating or filling with suitable material to such depth below finished grade line that when the depth of base material (when required by the Building Inspector) is compacted, the subgrade will be uniform and at the desired depth below finished grade lines before the forms are placed.
b) Base material shall consist of crushed rock, gravel or sand, with a suitable binding material, compacted by rolling or tamping. All components of this material shall be free from vegetable matter or balls of clay.
(Prior code 12.04.060)
Sec. 11-7. Concrete specifications.
a) Portland cement concrete shall be composed of Portland cement, fine and coarse aggregate, and water, proportioned and mixed in conformity with these specifications.
b) Portland cement shall conform to all requirements of the "Standard Specifications for Portland Cement," A.A.S.H.O. Specifications M-85-49 for Type II.
c) Air-entraining Portland cement shall conform to all requirements of the "Standard Specifications for Air-Entraining Portland Cement," A.A.S.H.O. Specification M-134-46 Type IIa.
(Prior code 12.04.070)
Sec. 11-8. Aggregate specifications.
a) Fine aggregate shall be composed of clean, hard, durable, uncoated particles of sand free from injurious amounts of clay, dust, soft or flaky particles, loam, shale, alkali, organic matter or other deleterious matter. Fine aggregate shall be well graded from coarse to fine.
b) The coarse aggregate shall consist of broken stone or gravel composed of clean, hard, durable stone, free from soft, thin, elongated or laminated pieces, disintegrated stone, clay, loam, vegetable matter or deleterious matter. Coarse aggregate shall be well graded; all must pass two-inch sieve size.
c) The use of pit-run aggregate as a mixture of fine and coarse aggregate shall not be permitted.
d) The combined aggregate shall consist of not less than one (1) part cement, two (2) parts fine aggregate and three (3) parts coarse aggregate (1x2x3) with a minimum amount of water to produce the required workability. Concrete shall be thoroughly mixed in an approved machine mixer of the batch type.
(Prior code 12.04.080)
Sec. 11-9. Mixing proportions and strength of concrete and aggregate.
Any approved method of mixing and proportioning cement and aggregate which has been or may be developed in the future shall be permissible, provided that the concrete shall have a minimum ultimate
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 227
compressive strength at twenty-eight (28) days of not less than three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch. Central-mixed or transit-mixed concrete shall be mixed and transported to the site of the work in accordance with "Standard Specifications for Ready-Mixed Concrete," A.S.T.M. Designation C-94-48.
(Prior code 12.04.090)
Sec. 11-10. Placement of concrete mixture; removal of defective material authorized when.
a) The method and manner of placing shall be such as to avoid the possibility of segregation or separation of the aggregates.
b) In all cases the mortar content of the mix shall be brought into proper contact with interior surfaces by spading and/or vibrating the concrete. The operation of depositing and compacting the concrete shall, in general, be conducted so as to form a compact, dense, impervious, artificial stone of uniform texture. If any section of concrete is found to be defective, it shall be removed or repaired as directed by the Building Inspector.
(Prior code 12.04.100)
Sec. 11-11. Forms used.
Steel forms or straight-grain, well-oiled wood forms of two-inch nominal dimension, of a height not less than the designed depth of the sidewalk, shall be used on all straight sections of sidewalks. Flexible forms shall be used for curves. Forms will not be necessary adjacent to existing curbs.
(Prior code 12.04.110)
Sec. 11-12. Finishing.
The concrete shall be struck off and finished true to cross-section. As soon as the concrete has attained sufficient hardness, the concrete shall be finished with a wood float and trowel. Final finish shall be obtained with a stiff brush or broom. The edges next to the forms and curb shall be rounded with the edging tools.
(Prior code 12.04.120)
Sec. 11-13. Expansion joint requirements.
Nonextruding premoulded expansion joints one (1) inch thick, conforming to all requirements of A.S.T.M. Specification D- 544, shall be placed at intervals not to exceed fifty (50) feet and at each cold joint, and shall extend through the entire depth of concrete.
(Prior code 12.04.130)
Sec. 11-14. Protection when newly completed.
When completed, the sidewalk shall be protected from the elements for at least two (2) days and the driveways shall be protected from vehicular traffic for at least seven (7) days.
(Prior code 12.04.140)
Sec. 11-15. Permit required for construction, repair or alteration.
No change, alteration, repair, replacement or construction of any sidewalk shall be made until the owner of the property adjoining such sidewalk shall obtain a permit for the same from the Town Clerk.
(Prior code 12.04.150)
Sec. 11-16. Assessment for construction by town.
Whenever the owners of the majority of the frontage of lots or lands adjacent to or abutting upon any street or designated portion thereof shall petition the Board of Trustees in writing to construct sidewalks along said street or designated portion thereof, it shall be the duty of the Board of Trustees to order said construction to be made and to assess the cost of said construction against the lots or lands adjacent to or abutting upon said street and to collect the same as provided by Section 31-15-704, C.R.S.
(Prior code 12.04.160)
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 228
Sec. 11-17. Board of trustees authority to construct or repair.
Whenever the Board of Trustees deems it necessary that any portion of a sidewalk be constructed or repaired, it may, on its own motion, order the same to be done, and if not constructed or repaired by the owner upon notice, the Town may construct or repair the same and assess the cost thereof against the adjacent property owner and collect the same as provided by Section 31-15-704, C.R.S.
(Prior code 12.04.170)
Sec. 11-18. Violation; notice to conform with regulations required; town may perform work when; costs.
Except as otherwise provided in Section 12.04.190 11-19, in the event of a violation of any of the regulations set forth in this Article, the Town Clerk shall give notice to the person or persons in violation, and said person or persons shall have twenty (20) days after the receipt of such notice within which to conform to the requirements of these regulations. The notice shall be served on the owner or agent in charge of the property if found within the Town, and if not, the notice may be served by United States mail addressed to the owner of the property at said owner's last known address, in which case notice shall be deemed served upon mailing. In the event such person or persons fail to conform to these regulations within the twenty-day period, the proper officials of the Town shall have the right to do all work and things necessary to bring about the conformity with these regulations and to charge the costs of such work and things to the person or persons in violation. Such costs shall be billed and assessed in accordance with the provisions of Section 11-20.
(Prior code 12.04.180)
Sec. 11-19. Violation; obstructions and snow removal; town may perform work; costs.
In the event a person fails to remove snow or ice from sidewalks in front of, adjacent to, or alongside property owned or occupied by him or her within the applicable time periods provided in Section 11-1, or in the event a person fails to remove mud, dirt, rubbish, filth or any other obstructions from such sidewalks within forty-eight (48) hours after such obstructions accumulate upon such sidewalks, in violation of Section 11-1, the proper officials of the Town shall have the right, immediately and without notice to the person in violation, to do all work and things necessary to remove such snow, ice or obstructions and to charge the costs of such work and things to the person or persons in violation. Such costs shall be billed and assessed in accordance with the provisions of Section 12.04.200 11-20.
(Prior code 12.04.190)
Sec. 11-20. Payment procedures; lien for unpaid charges; cumulative effect.
a) Within seven (7) days after doing work and any other things necessary to bring about conformity with the regulation set forth in this Article, pursuant to Sections 11-18 or 11-19, the Town shall bill the person or persons in violation for the costs of such work and things, including five percent (5%) for inspection and other incidental costs in connection therewith. The costs so billed shall be due and payable within thirty (30) days from the date of such billing, and a penalty of ten percent (10%) may be assessed for late payment.
b) All such costs for bringing about conformity with the regulations contained in this Article shall also constitute a lien upon any lots, land, building or premises abutting the affected sidewalks, and in the event said costs shall not be paid when due, the Town Clerk may certify the charge to the County Treasurer to be placed by him or her upon the tax list for the current year to be collected in the manner as other taxes are collected, with ten percent (10%) per annum added thereto to defray the costs of collection, and all state laws for the assessment and collection of general taxes, including the laws for the sale of property for taxes and redemption of the same, shall apply.
(Prior code 12.04.200)
Sec. 11-21. Unlawful to violate this article; payment of assessment will not avoid fine.
It is unlawful for any owner or occupant to violate or otherwise to fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of this Article and, upon any conviction, any such owner shall be subject to the provisions of Section 1-82. The fact that costs have been billed or assessments have been made against property as provided in this Article shall not prevent the owner from being punished by fine or jailing under the general
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 229
provisions of this Code, but such fine or penalty may be imposed on those found guilty of violating the provisions of this Article in all cases, whether costs have been billed or paid or an assessment has or has not been made in accordance with the provisions of this Article.
(Prior code 12.04.210)
Secs. 11-22—11-40. Reserved.
ARTICLE II Excavations

Sec. 11-41. Permit and compliance with article regulations required.
It is unlawful for any person to make any excavation in any street, alley or other public place in the Town without obtaining a permit therefor as provided herein, or without complying with the provisions of this Article.
(Prior code 12.08.010)
Sec. 11-42. Application for permit; contents and fee required; time limit for completion of work.
Application for permit shall be made to the Town Clerk on forms supplied by the Town and shall show the location of the intended excavation, the size, the purpose for which it is made, the name and address of the person making such excavation and the name and address of the person for whom the work is being done. Each application for a permit shall state the length of time it is estimated will elapse from the commencement of work until the entire area affected by the proposed excavation is restored to its original condition. Failure to meet the time requirements set forth on the permit shall be considered a violation of this Article. No application shall be considered without payment, as set by fee schedule, to the Town Clerk as an application fee. Application forms may be prepared by the Town Administrator or the Town Clerk for use pursuant to this Article.
(Prior code 12.08.020; Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 875 §1, 2002)
Sec. 11-43. Permit issuance; town supervisor order required.
No such permit shall be issued excepting on an order of the Town Administrator or the Town Clerk.
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 230
(Prior code 12.08.030; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 11-44. Permit issuance; bond required.
No permit shall be issued unless the applicant has filed with the Town Clerk a bond in the amount of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), which shall protect the Town against any loss or liability which may result from the making of the excavation. The bond shall also guarantee the payment to the Town for any expense incurred in replacing paving or other surface grading. Such bond shall have as a surety a corporation licensed to do business in the State as a surety company. In addition, the applicant shall submit with the application evidence satisfactory to the Town Administrator or the Town Clerk that the applicant is insured at the time of the application and will be insured through the proposed excavation project against liability for personal injuries and property damage that may in any way arise from or be connected with the proposed excavation work.
(Prior code 12.08.040; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 11-45. Appropriate warning devices required; unlawful to remove or tamper with such warning devices.
Any applicant authorized to make an excavation shall at all times provide such warning devices, signs or lights in accordance with the latest edition of the manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. It is unlawful for any person to remove or tamper with such warning devices with the intent of leaving the excavation without appropriate warning devices.
(Prior code 12.08.050)
Sec. 11-46. Method of excavation.
The excavation shall be made in such a manner as not to injure any facilities, utilities or other structures already in the ground, and proper bracing shall be provided to prevent caving of ditch banks.
(Prior code 12.08.060)
Sec. 11-47. Material excavated for buildings.
Material that is excavated during the construction of buildings and materials that are to be used to backfill foundations or complete the landscaping of any property shall not be stored on the property for a period in excess of one hundred eighty (180) days. Materials that are located on properties in excess of one hundred eighty (180) days may be removed by the Town or its designated contractor and the property owner will be responsible for reimbursement to the Town for the cost of removal and costs of collection, including attorney's fees.
(Ord. 684, 1993)
Sec. 11-48. Excavations across streets or under sidewalks; procedures required.
If the proposed excavation is designed to cross a street, alleyway or other public way, not more than one-half (½) the width of such street, alleyway or other public way shall be closed at any one (1) time. If the excavation is across a sidewalk area, a safe and convenient temporary walk shall be provided.
(Prior code 12.08.070)
Sec. 11-49. Material excavated for streets.
Material that is excavated during the construction of streets, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, and materials to be used to bring properties to proper grade, shall not be stored on property within the Town for a period in excess of sixty (60) days. Materials that are located on properties in excess of sixty (60) days may be removed by the Town or its designated contractor and the property owner or developer will be responsible to reimburse the Town for the cost of removal and costs of collection, including attorney's fees.
(Ord. 684, 1993)
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 231
Sec. 11-50. Longitudinal excavation; approval of location required.
If the excavation is to be placed longitudinally along a street, alley or other public way, the location shall be approved by the Town Administrator.
(Prior code 12.08.080)
Sec. 11-51. Time for completion of work.
The excavation shall be made and backfilled in the shortest time possible. If the work is stopped more than seventy-two (72) hours, the excavation shall be backfilled and the surface made available for the same use or uses as were made of the surface prior to the excavation. The excavation shall then be reopened when the work can proceed, but only with the approval of the Town Administrator.
(Prior code 12.08.090)
Sec. 11-52. Width restrictions; sod to be preserved for replacement.
No excavation shall be more than twenty-four (24) inches in width unless approved by the Town Administrator and so indicated in the permit. When making an excavation in a paved street, the pavement shall be cut in a straight line entirely through the pavement the exact size of the contemplated excavation. The excavation below the surface shall not at any point extend beyond the opening at the surface. If the excavation is in a park or other grassed area, the sod shall be carefully removed and preserved for replacement or the area reseeded.
(Prior code 12.08.100)
Sec. 11-53. Backfill requirements.
In backfilling an excavation, the dirt removed from the hole shall be put back in the hole. Backfill shall be tamped to specifications approved by the Town Administrator and the surface of the backfill shall be even with the adjacent surface. If rocks are hauled away, an equal amount of volume of suitable dirt shall be hauled in to replace the rock removed. No rocks or other lump material larger than two (2) inches at the point of largest diameter shall be used in backfilling. The backfill shall be completed in such a manner as to leave the street, alley or other public place in which the excavation was made in as good and stable condition as it was prior to the making of the excavation.
(Prior code 12.08.110)
Sec. 11-54. Tunneling prohibited without permission.
No tunnel shall be permitted under any street or sidewalk unless permission is first obtained from the Town Administrator and such permission is so indicated in the permit, if granted.
(Prior code 12.08.120)
Sec. 11-55. Paving repairs.
Repairs to the pavement shall be made by the permittee or his or her duly authorized agent.
(Prior code 12.08.130)
Sec. 11-56. Emergency permits authorized when.
In case of emergency, temporary verbal permits may be given by the Town Administrator.
(Prior code 12.08.140)
Sec. 11-57. Surface replacement or repair requirements.
Repairing and replacing of the surface of a street, alley or sidewalk or other public way or the sod in a park or ground area injured or removed by such excavation must be done to the satisfaction of the Town Administrator.
(Prior code 12.08.150)
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 232
Sec. 11-58. Completion of work by town authorized when; costs.
In case the work is not completed to the satisfaction of the Town Administrator within the time allowed by the permit, the filling in, repairing and surfacing shall be done by the Town and charged to the person doing the excavating. If these charges are not paid within ten (10) days of the billing date, the charges shall carry interest at the rate of twelve percent (12%) per annum and the applicant shall be responsible for the Town Attorney's fees and all court costs.
(Prior code 12.08.160)
Sec. 11-59. Permit not required when.
The provisions of this Article relative to securing permits shall not apply to officers or employees of the Town engaged in doing work for the Town; nor to persons doing work for the Town under contract; nor to persons which are operating under a franchise or grant from the Town, if such franchise provides for making of excavations or tunnels without securing a permit therefor.
(Prior code 12.08.170)
Sec. 11-60. Road and bridge specifications.
Pursuant to Title 31, Article 16, Parts 1 and 2, C.R.S., there is adopted by reference the Mesa County Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction as adopted March 28, 1995 by the Mesa County Commissioners and as amended from time to time by the Commissioners. The subject matter of the Mesa County Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction relates to the construction of roads and bridges in the Town with the exception of the centerline radius of a nonthrough "urban residential street" for which a centerline radius as sharp as one hundred (100) feet may be considered if physical conditions justify the need for a sharper curve.
(Ord. 693, 1994; Ord. 867 §1, 2001)
Sec. 11-61. Driveways.
No person shall construct any driveway providing vehicular access to or from any Town street or across property adjoining a Town street, except as part of an approved subdivision, without a driveway permit. All driveways shall be constructed in accordance with plans and details approved by the Town as specified in the Mesa County Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction.
(Ord. 693, 1994)
Secs. 11-62—11-70. Reserved.
ARTICLE III Building Numbering [and] Street Naming [1]
Sec. 11-71. Compliance with Article provisions required.
Sec. 11-72. Numbering required; placement restrictions.
Sec. 11-73. Numbering system described.
Sec. 11-74. General subdivision and street naming guidelines and standards.
Sec. 11-75. Material and height of numbers.
Sec. 11-76. Time limit for compliance with provisions.
Secs. 11-77—11-90. Reserved.
Sec. 11-71. Compliance with Article provisions required.
As deemed necessary by Public Safety and Planning the Town of Palisade will establish a uniform system for street naming and addressing procedures for new developments and as needed for existing properties with no known address or with addressing inconsistencies. Addressing should be done in a way that encourages efficient and timely delivery of services such as police, fire, ambulance, and mail and other deliveries; a community sense of location; and ease of navigation for visitors and new comers. Any and all parcels, buildings and structures which may be constructed after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Article in the Town shall be subject to the provisions of this Article, and numbered in the manner herein prescribed. From time to time the Town of Palisade will review existing addresses and may be required to update those existing addresses to meet these standards.
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 233
(Ord. 2014-05, §1)
Sec. 11-72. Numbering required; placement restrictions.
It is hereby made the duty of every owner or his or her agent or the occupant of any parcel, building or structure situated in the corporate limits of the Town to number the same within thirty (30) days after being notified to do so by the Town Clerk, in the manner hereinafter directed, and by securely fastening a metal plate or sign bearing the figures necessary to indicate the proper number of any said parcel, building or structure in a prominent place, whichever shall be the most visible from the street upon which such parcel, building or structure fronts.
(Ord. 2014-05, §1)
Sec. 11-73. Numbering system described.
The proper number to be affixed to any such parcel, building or structure shall be ascertained in the following manner, to wit:
1. Beginning at that certain street in Town known as Main Street, as a base point, and proceeding easterly and westerly from Main Street, all parcels, buildings and structures fronting upon streets running at right angles therewith shall be numbered in accordance with what is known as the decimal system, and by regularly increasing numbers, according to the distance easterly or westerly from said Main Street, allowing one (1) number to each twelve and one-half (12½) feet of space in each block, exclusive of alleys.
2. Parcels, buildings and structures situated upon Main Street, and upon all other streets running parallel or nearly parallel therewith, shall be numbered by the same method and in the same manner, using that certain street in the Town known as First Street as a base point, and proceeding northerly and southerly therefrom.
3. Numbers in each block shall begin with 100 and 101, 200 and 201, 300 and 301, etc., according to whether the same is the first, second or third, etc., block from the streets designated as base points. On all streets or avenues running northerly and southerly, even numbers shall be placed on the west side of the street, and on streets and avenues running easterly and westerly, even numbers shall be placed on the north side of the street. The odd numbers in each case shall be placed on the side of the street opposite to that on which the even numbers are to be placed, as aforesaid.
4. Multiple addresses may be assigned per parcel. If this does occur, 911 mapping shall be notified in order for the Address Points map to be updated and the Assessor's Office so the property information is kept current.
5. If there is more than one (1) unit on the parcel a unit number/letter must be assigned. Do not use alpha numeric combinations (i.e. A2, 3B).
6. Unit numbers/letters shall be assigned incrementally increasing with the street numbering.
7. Do not use the "#" symbol in any portion of an address. Use "Unit," "Ste," "Suite," "Trl," "Apt," etc.
8. Accessory buildings or structures shall maintain the same address as the primary parcel, building, or structure and may receive a unit number.
9. The number which, by proper computation and measurement, made in accordance with the foregoing provisions, falls to any parcel, building or structure in the Town, as computed from the official plat of the Town, shall thenceforth be and remain the proper and official number thereof.
10. Notification of a Change of Address/Address Assignment or newly addressed subdivision plat needs to be available to all utilities, districts, and agencies with an interest in said property.
(Ord. 2014-05, §1)
Sec. 11-74. General subdivision and street naming guidelines and standards.
The proper naming of a street or renaming of street shall be ascertained using the guidelines and standards prepared by Public Safety, Planning, in coordination with service-providing agencies (911, post office, GIS, etc.)
1. Do not allow the use of fractions in the street number or street name.
2. Punctuation should not be used in subdivision or street names.
3. All new subdivisions shall be reviewed at both preliminary and final review stages for conformance with street naming conventions and to identify any potential addressing issues (i.e. fractions, duplicate street or subdivision names, loop w/not enough numbers).
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 234
4. Private streets shall be named and used for addressing; however, private drives/shared drives/auto-courts shall not be named or used for addressing unless no other alternative exists.
5. Do not use special characters in road names (dashes, hyphens, apostrophes).
6. Do not use "North," "South," "East," "West" or street types as a street name (North Crest, South Camp, Court Street, Avenue of Pines Road, North Boulevard).
7. No duplicate names allowed, even across jurisdictions in the urbanized area.
8. If a street name sounds like another name and is spelled different, than a new name must be proposed. (Karla and Carla)
9. Streets that are in alignment and may connect in the future shall use the existing street name even if there is a disruption in the connection. If the connection will never happen due to existing development(s) or physical barrier(s), the name may be, but is not required to be different. Addresses may extend somewhat beyond the grid if needed under the same circumstances as mentioned above.
10. When reviewing a new plat and/or addressing circle or horseshoe roads, it is often easiest to split the road and rename it where it makes a ninety-degree turn or more so that addresses can be assigned without running out of numbers. This will not always be the case, use your best judgment.
11. Streets that make a ninety-degree turn should be renamed if it extends for more than three hundred (300) feet to maintain the integrity of the addressing grid and maximize available numbers.
12. A local road that begins and circles back to terminate on the same road shall be designated as a "circle or loop".
13. “Courts" shall be in alignment with the street that is name after. The best place to make the break from a "Street" to a "Court" is after it has passed over a perpendicular road (intersection). Courts at right angles to a street shall receive a name substantially different from that street.
(Ord. 2014-05, §1)
Sec. 11-75. Material and height of numbers.
The figures used to indicate the number of each house, building or structure in the Town, and to be placed upon the metal plates or signs mentioned in Section 11-72, shall each be at least three (3) inches in height and so inscribed and placed as to be plainly visible from the street upon which the house, building or structure bearing the number is situated.
(Ord. 2014-05, §1)
Sec. 11-76. Time limit for compliance with provisions.
The owner or occupant of any house, building or structure in the Town who is notified as hereinbefore provided of the proper number therefor, shall have thirty (30) days to comply with the provisions of this Article before he or she is subject to any penalty.
(Ord. 2014-05, §1)
Secs. 11-77—11-90. Reserved.
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. 2014-05, adopted March 11, 2014, amended Art. III in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 11-71—11-75 pertained to building numbering and derived from prior code 12.12.010—12.12.040, 12.12.060; and Ord. 685 § 1, adopted in 1993. (Back)

Sec. 11-91. Created; survey and map authorized and filed.
There is created a municipal cemetery, consisting of land owned by the Town, or hereafter acquired to be used for the burial and internment of human bodies. The Town has caused the municipal cemetery to be surveyed and mapped by a registered land surveyor and the map to be accepted and declared to be the official map and plat of the Palisade Municipal Cemetery, and the Mayor and Town Clerk are hereby authorized and directed to sign the map on behalf of the Town and cause the same to be recorded in the Mesa County Clerk's office, and a copy of the map shall be filed in the office of the Town Clerk.
(Prior code 12.16.010; Ord. 2014-10 §1)
Sec. 11-92. Rules and regulations; board of trustees authority.
The Board of Trustees shall from time to time establish rules and regulations concerning the operation of the cemetery, and such rules and regulations may be amended and changed by the Board of Trustees at any meeting of the Board. The rules and regulations so established shall be binding upon all persons using the cemetery facilities.
(Prior code 12.16.020)
Sec. 11-93. Control and management responsibility.
The Town Clerk has the right of general control and management of the cemetery and shall delegate the duties involved to the Park and Cemetery Superintendent who in turn shall be responsible to the Town Administrator or Town Clerk for direct and complete supervision of the cemetery in all matters. The Town Clerk shall report to the Board of Trustees the financial and physical status of the cemetery and cemetery funds.
(Prior code 12.16.030; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 11-94. Annual budget; town administrator duty.
The Town Administrator and Town Clerk shall prepare an annual cemetery budget, incorporating such allocation of funds as may be necessary for proper management, in a manner consistent with all budgeting requirements.
(Prior code 12.16.040; Ord. 685 §1, 1993)
Sec. 11-95. Recordkeeping duties; issuance of permits, certificates and contracts.
The Town Clerk shall keep and have custody of all books and records pertaining to the cemetery, and shall issue all permits for the burial, internment, disinternment and removal of bodies in said cemetery. The Town Administrator and the Town Clerk shall execute and issue, to those having paid therefor, grant of internment rights to burial space agreements in such form as the Board of Trustees and the Town Administrator may determine, and in compliance with the provisions of this Article and any and all rules and regulations of the Town and State laws.
(Prior code 12.16.050; Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 2014-10 §2)
Sec. 11-96. Grant of internment rights.
a) As of January 1, 2009, the Town of Palisade discontinued its policy to allow the reservation of burial space through a payment plan. Cemetery spaces can be reserved in advance of need. A person desiring to reserve internment rights in the municipal cemetery must pay in full at the time of the reservation of a burial space, with the exception of the opening and closing fees and vault setting fees. If and when the current grantee of a reservation of burial space elects to assign the burial space described above to another grantee, the Town reserves the right to cancel the grant of internment rights to a burial space so long as the Town refunds the price paid at the time the grant of internment rights to burial space agreement was entered into.
b) If there is a burial space in the Palisade Municipal Cemetery in which no remains have been interred, no burial memorial has been placed, and no other improvement has been made for a continuous period of no less than seventy-five (75) years, the Board of Trustees may initiate the process of
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 236
reclaiming the reservation of burial space in accordance with the requirements of Section 31-25-708, C.R.S.
(Ord. 2014-10 §4)
Sec. 11-97. Schedule of charges and report of income and expenses.
The Board of Trustees shall request the Town Clerk to report as conditions warrant on the income and expenses of the cemetery, and shall adopt by resolution a schedule of prices for:
1. Grave space;
2. Opening and closing graves;
3. Services incident to burials, disinterment, removal or reburial of bodies;
4. Constructing foundations for monuments and markers; and
5. Special protective measures for monuments and markers, consistent with prevailing conditions.
(Prior code 12.16.060; Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 2014-10, §3)
Editor's note— Section 3 of Ord. 2014-10, adopted July 22, 2014 renumbered former § 11-96 as § 11-97.
Sec. 11-98. Payment of operating expense claims.
Claims for payment of labor, equipment and general operating expenses of the municipal cemetery shall be presented at regular Board of Trustees meetings, and the same method of approval and authorization of payment shall be used as in other municipal departments, charging all expense to the General Fund.
(Prior code 12.16.070; Ord. 2014-10, §3)
Editor's note— Section 3 of Ord. 2014-10, adopted July 22, 2014 renumbered former § 11-97 as § 11-98.
Secs. 11-99—11-110. Reserved.

ARTICLE VI Street Maintenance
Sec. 11-131. Street classification.
Sec. 11-132. Street classification map.

Sec. 11-131. Street classification.
Streets within the Town are hereby divided into classifications as shown on the official Street Classification Map of the Town, which together with all explanatory material thereon, is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this Chapter. The map does not change boundaries or legal rights of record; rather it graphically depicts the status of streets within the Town.
(Ord. 751 §1, 1996)
Sec. 11-132. Street classification map.
The official Street Classification Map, which shall be located in the office of the Town Clerk, shall be identified by the signature of the Mayor and attested by the Town Clerk and shall bear the seal of the Town under the following words: "This is to certify that this is the official Street Classification Map referred to in Section 11-132 of the Palisade Town Code." together with the date of adoption of this Article.
(Ord. 751 §1, 1996)
Sec. 11-133. Status of streets.
The Official Street Classification Map does not change boundaries or legal right-of-record, but rather graphically depicts the status of streets within the Town. This Article does not assume liability other than as provided by law and does not relieve the developers or constructors responsibility. Where uncertainty exists as to the boundaries of streets as shown on the official Street Classification Map, the Map is a general representation and is subordinate to documents of record. For streets accepted, the Town has accepted the entire right-of-way and the improvements constructed thereon. This Article does not affect the owner's responsibility for sidewalks as set forth in this Chapter.
(Ord. 751 §1, 1996)
Sec. 11-134. Boundary changes.
If, in accordance with the amendment provisions of this Chapter, changes are made in district boundaries or other matters shown on the official Street Classification Map, such changes shall be made promptly after the amendment has been approved by the Board of Trustees together with an entry on the official Street Classification Map noting the date of the change and a brief description of the nature of the change, which entry shall be signed by the Mayor and attested by the Town Clerk. The amending ordinance shall provide that such changes or amendments shall not become effective until they have been duly entered upon the official Street Classification Map. No amendments of this Article which involve matters shown on the official Street Classification Map shall become effective until after such change and entry have been made on said map.
(Ord. 751 §1, 1996)
Sec. 11-135. Other changes.
No changes of any nature shall be made on the official Street Classification Map or matters shown thereon except in conformance with the procedures set forth in this Article. Any unauthorized change of whatever kind by any person or persons shall be considered a violation of this Article and punishable as provided in this Code.
(Ord. 751 §1, 1996)
CHAPTER 11 Streets, Sidewalks and Other Public Property
Page 238
Sec. 11-136. Replacement map.
In the event that the official Street Classification Map becomes damaged, destroyed, lost or difficult to interpret because of nature or number of changes and additions, the Board of Trustees may by resolution adopt a new official Street Classification Map, which shall supersede the prior official Map. The new official Classification Map may correct drafting or other errors in the prior official Street Classification Map, but no such correction shall have the effect of amending the original street classification ordinance or any subsequent amendment thereto.
(Ord. 751 §1, 1996)
Secs. 11-137—11-150. Reserved.

Sec. 13-1. Definitions.
As used in this Chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated:
Accessory dwelling unit (ADU) shall mean a separate additional living unit, including separate kitchen, sleeping and bathroom facilities, attached or detached from the primary residential unit on a single-family lot.
Condominiumization shall mean the creation of individual air space units in a building, together with the formation of interest in the common elements appurtenant to those units. There is common ownership and the formation of an association to govern the use of property and the writing of covenants to regulate the use of property and protect the interests of the different owners.
Distribution main shall mean any main or line within the Town right-of-way or dedicated easement owned by the Town for the purpose of a domestic water supply.
Notice shall mean information deemed to have been given if delivered personally to the party in question or mailed, postage prepaid, to the last known address of the party in question.
Premises shall mean a tract of land, including its buildings.
Service line shall mean the water line running from the meter pit to the property of the user being supplied with water.
Tap shall mean the connection made by the Town from the distribution main to the property side of the meter pit.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2012-03 §1)
Sec. 13-2. Permit required; one tap per premises; cross-connections prohibited.
a) No person, his or her family or their agents shall use the water from any part of the waterworks without authorization. No person without lawful authority shall open any fire hydrant, stopcock, valve or other fixture appurtenant to said waterworks, nor shall any person shut off or turn on water for any service line without lawful authority.
b) Only one (1) premises shall be supplied with water through a single service line connected to the Town distribution system. In the event a premises receiving water through the system is divided into separate ownership, each owner shall be required to have a separate service line connected to the distribution main and each additional user shall pay the applicable tap fee to the Town. In the event
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 240
that an accessory dwelling unit (ADU) or the condominiumization of the existing building is permitted, a separate service line will not be required.
c) No cross-connection will be permitted whereby anything other than water supplied by the Town is permitted to enter the Town distribution system. All premises shall meet the requirements of the Town's cross-connection control program as established by Resolution 2004-37. Backflow preventers shall meet or exceed the requirements stated in the most current publication of the American Water Works Association Standard C506-78 or meet Sections 25-1-107, 25-1-109 and 25-1-114, C.R.S., and the Colorado Primary Drinking Water Regulations, Article 14, whichever is more stringent.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2012-03 §2)
Sec. 13-3. Service; authority required.
All persons who desire to use water from the municipal waterworks system shall seek appropriate authority from the Town Clerk and remit all appropriate fees. This shall include tap fees, as well as reimbursement for the actual cost of connecting the service line to the distribution main. All service connections are subject to review, and, in the event that a review by the Town Engineer or other consultant is required, the Town shall require the applicant to pay all costs for such services.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 895 §1, 2003; Ord. 2012-03 §3)
Sec. 13-4. Article provisions considered contract between town and in town or out-of-town property owner.
The provisions of this Article, so far as applicable, shall be considered as a part of the contract between the Town and each property owner who is furnished with Town water, and each property owner, by using Town water or allowing Town water to be used, shall be presumed to express his or her consent to be bound by all the provisions of this Article or such others as the Town may hereafter adopt. Inhabitants of areas outside the Town limits and within the defined service area may be permitted to purchase domestic water service from the Town by connection into its distribution system after execution of a signed agreement with the Town.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2012-03 §4)
Sec. 13-5. Rules and regulations; scope.
a) The Town shall have the right to adopt rules and regulations controlling the usage of water from the municipal water system, and such rules and regulations shall be binding upon all persons using water from said water system.
b) Any change in the present regulations controlling the use of such water shall be given by United States mail to the property owner involved or by public notice of such change published one (1) time-in the Palisade Tribune.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000)
Sec. 13-6. Service lines; ownership and responsibility for maintenance.
Individual service lines are the sole responsibility of and owned by the property owner. The owner of any property which receives water from the municipal water system shall keep his or her service line protected and in good condition to prevent the wasting of water. If wasting of water occurs due to the condition of said service line, the owner shall repair or replace said service line and stop the leak. In the event such leakage is not immediately stopped by the owner or lessee, the Town, without notice, may discontinue water service to the property until such time as the leak is repaired, or the Town may repair the leak and assess the cost of such repairs to the property.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000)
Sec. 13-7. Access for inspection authorized when; town right to shut off service.
a) Town Public Works Department employees shall have free access (at reasonable hours) to the premises served with water to inspect and ascertain the condition of all hydrants, pipes, valves and fixtures attached to said water system.
b) Should any private service line or private appurtenance connected to the municipal water system be found causing a waste of water and in need of repair, the Town shall have the right to shut off the
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 241
water line leading to such property, and the same shall not be turned on again until the required repairs are made.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2012-03 §5)
Sec. 13-8. Wasting water prohibited.
No person shall permit water to waste upon his or her premises or upon the premises of any other person from any private service line or private appurtenance connected to the municipal water system.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000)
Sec. 13-9. Extension of water mains.
Any person desiring to extend a water main within the Town shall make written application to the Town Administrator which describes the property to be served, the scope and timetable for any development and the probable flow requirements of said development. Upon written approval granted by the Town, construction will proceed according to written rules and regulations adopted by the Town.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2012-03 §6)
Sec. 13-10. Wells and cisterns prohibited.
Water service within the Town shall be provided from mains only. Water wells and cisterns for domestic water use are prohibited.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000)
Sec. 13-11. Tampering with or obstructing fire hydrants, valves or other equipment prohibited.
No person shall tamper with any fire hydrant, main line valve or other appurtenance connected to the municipal water system.
(Ord. 853 §1 & §2, 2000)
Secs. 13-12—13-20. Reserved.
ARTICLE II Water Rates
Sec. 13-21. Tap and connection fees.
Sec. 13-22. Monthly water charges; general.
Sec. 13-23. Monthly water charges.
Sec. 13-24. Purpose.
Sec. 13-25. Penalty for unlawful reconnection.
