Sec. 13-21. Tap and connection fees.
a) Prior to the approval of a zoning clearance for new construction and prior to the connection of a water meter if the construction is outside the Town limits, proof shall be presented that the appropriate water tap has been purchased.
b) Water taps, once issued, remain with the property and shall not be transferred to another property. Tap fees (plant investment fees) shall be paid in full prior to the installation of a water meter. A schedule of the Town's tap fees (plant investment fees) shall be promulgated from time to time by resolution of the Board of Trustees.
c) A water connection charge, separate and distinct from the tap fees, shall be assessed on all water services installed and shall be determined based upon the cost of all material and labor necessary to install any such water service.
d) Larger water service connections may be installed upon request, and the charges incurred shall reflect the additional cost of labor and materials as determined by the Town Administrator.
(Ord. 831 §1, 2000; Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 896 §1, 2003; Ord. 2005-03 §1)
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 242
Sec. 13-22. Monthly water charges; general.
Each residential dwelling unit, mobile home dwelling unit, manufactured home dwelling unit, mobile/manufactured home park owner/ manager, business and industry shall be assessed and shall pay monthly water charges in accordance with this Article. The monthly water charges shall constitute a lien on the property.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2012-03 §7)
Sec. 13-23. Monthly water charges.
a) All properties connected to the Town water system shall be assessed and shall pay monthly water charges in accordance with this Section. The individual, individuals or entities in whose name the billing is listed by the Town, or property owner, shall pay the monthly water charges. Unpaid monthly water charges shall constitute a lien on the property.
b) The monthly charges shall consist of two (2) components: (1) the monthly minimum water service charge; and (2) the monthly water volume charge.
1. Monthly minimum water service charge. A schedule of the Town's monthly minimum water service charges shall be promulgated from time to time by resolution of the Board of Trustees.
a. A mobile/manufactured home park owner/manager shall pay the monthly minimum water service charge for each mobile/manufactured home dwelling unit within the park only after the initial dwelling unit is placed on the lot and connected to the water system. From the time of initial connection, said monthly water availability of service charge shall continue to be in effect regardless of whether the dwelling unit is occupied or vacant.
b. Each residential dwelling unit, mobile home dwelling unit, mobile home park/subdivision, business and industry listed by the Town as an active water account shall be assessed and shall pay minimum water service charges. A schedule of such minimum water service charges shall be promulgated from time to time by resolution of the Board of Trustees. Such charges are in addition to water volume charges.
2. Monthly water volume charge. Each residential dwelling unit, mobile home dwelling unit, mobile/manufactured home park/subdivision, business and industry which utilizes more than the minimum gallons of water in any month shall be assessed and shall pay monthly water volume charges.
3. For each multi-unit property, business or residential, a full monthly service fee shall be charged for the first unit. Each unit thereafter shall be assessed at seventy percent (70%) of the monthly service fee regardless of occupancy.
c) A schedule of such monthly water volume charges shall be promulgated from time to time by resolution of the Board of Trustees.
d) Upon repair of a leak or break in a customer's service line and upon receipt of a written request, one-half (½) of all overages based on the previous year's history of use can be waived by the Town Administrator. This is done to promote the rapid repair of water leaks and the reduction of wasted water.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 882 §1, 2002; Ord. 2005-03 §§2-4; Ord. 2012-03 §8)
Sec. 13-24. Purpose.
The Board of Trustees hereby finds, determines and declares:
a) All monthly water, sewer and refuse charges shall be collected by the duly authorized officials of the Town who shall, on or about the first day of each month, bill the utility users and collect the charges established pursuant to this Article and applicable resolutions of the Board of Trustees. The utility charges shall be due and payable no later than the twentieth day of each month. In the event that the monthly utility bills are not paid by five (5) days after the due date, a delinquency charge in an amount promulgated by resolution of the Board of Trustees shall be assessed and collected. Such delinquency charges may be assessed and shall continue to accrue regardless of whether the utility services are disconnected by the Town pursuant to any provisions of this Chapter or any other chapter of this Code.
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 243
b) In the event that the monthly utility bill remains unpaid for a period of one hundred twenty (120) days, water will be shut off to said property. The Town shall work with and make payment arrangements with any customer that is not able to pay all delinquent fees in full. However, in the event that the water is disconnected, all minimum utility fees shall continue to be assessed, and a disconnect/reconnect fee in an amount promulgated by resolution shall be assessed as well. In order for water service to be reinstated, all fees must be paid in full.
c) All rates, fees, charges and assessments provided by this Article II of Chapter 13 of the Palisade Municipal Code, from the time the same shall become due and payable, shall become and remain a lien on the premises until said rates, fees, charges and assessments have been paid to the Town. This lien on the premises may be foreclosed by an action at law or in equity in the name of the Town in any Court having jurisdiction thereof. If the Town must resort to court action for collection of amounts due it under this Article, the Town shall be entitled to its reasonable attorney's fees (including legal assistance fees) and other expenses incurred in such action if the Town prevails. In the event said rates, fees, charges and assessments are not paid when due, the Town Treasurer may file a notice of such lien in the records of the Mesa County Clerk and Recorder. In addition, the Town Treasurer may certify the amount of the same to the Mesa County Treasurer, to be placed on the tax list for the current year and to be collected in the same manner as other taxes are collected, with ten percent (10%) added thereto to defray the cost of collection, pursuant to Section 31-20-105, C.R.S. All laws of this State for the assessment and collection of general taxes, including the laws for the sale of property for taxes and redemption of the same, shall apply.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2005-03 §§5,6; Ord. 2009-09 §1; Ord. 2012-03 §9; Ord. 2014-17, §1)
Sec. 13-25. Penalty for unlawful reconnection.
It is unlawful, after water service has been disconnected, for any person to reconnect the same without the consent of the Town. Any person violating this provision shall be summoned into Municipal Court and upon conviction thereof shall incur such fine as imposed by the Municipal Court Judge pursuant to the this Code.
(Ord. 853 §1 & §2, 2000)
Secs. 13-26—13-40. Reserved.
ARTICLE III Water Meters
Sec. 13-41. Installation required; purpose.
Sec. 13-42. Service terminated unless consumer permits meter installation; liability.
Sec. 13-43. Service charges when meter operates incorrectly.
Sec. 13-44. Damage to water meters, remote readouts; wiring, repair fees.
Sec. 13-45. Restrictions on claims for breakage of pipe or facilities.
Secs. 13-46—13-80. Reserved.
Sec. 13-41. Installation required; purpose.
Every consumer using water from the municipal water system shall be required to have the Town install a water meter whose type and configuration shall be determined by the Town Administrator. All meters installed shall be owned and maintained by the Town. Each meter shall be used to measure the quantity of water used by each consumer and each consumer shall pay charges based upon the class of use as set forth in Section 13-23 above.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000)
Sec. 13-42. Service terminated unless consumer permits meter installation; liability.
Each water consumer shall be given at least three (3) days' notice of the intention of the Town to locate a water meter on that consumer's property. The meter shall be located on the consumer's property as agreed upon by the Town Administrator and the property owner. If the consumer shall then refuse or otherwise not allow the Town employee to install the water meter on the consumer's property, the Town may then, without further notice, terminate water service to that consumer. Water service may be
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 244
resumed by the Town when the consumer allows the Town to install a water meter on the consumer's property and the consumer has paid a fee to the Town, representing the cost of turning the water service off and on. The amount of said fee shall be promulgated from time to time by resolution of the Board of Trustees. Neither the Town nor its employees shall be liable for any damages of any kind to the consumer or his or her property as a result of the termination of water service when the consumer has refused to allow the installation of a water meter on his or her property.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2005-03 §7)
Sec. 13-43. Service charges when meter operates incorrectly.
When a meter fails to operate correctly, the monthly use charge shall be based on the quantity of water used during the previous billing period in which the meter was correctly operating.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000)
Sec. 13-44. Damage to water meters, remote readouts; wiring, repair fees.
a) Whenever any water meter, remote water meter readout, radio-read meter antenna or wiring for such shall be damaged, the property owner or the tenant shall be liable for the repairs as follows:
1. First occurrence in any calendar year: the cost of expenses, plus the estimated cost of water delivered through the system while the meter and/or readout were inoperative.
2. Second occurrence in any calendar year: the amounts provided in Subparagraph (1) above, plus a fifty-dollar service fee.
3. Third occurrence in any calendar year: the amounts provided in Subparagraphs (1) and (2) of this Subsection, plus a five-hundred-dollar cash bond shall be deposited with the Town Administrator as a guarantee of payment for future damage. Water service shall not be reinstated prior to receipt of said cash bond.
b) For the purposes of this Section, the term damage specifically excludes normal wear to the internal moving parts of the meter and remote meter readout.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2012-03 §10)
Sec. 13-45. Restrictions on claims for breakage of pipe or facilities.
Unless damage to property can be shown and substantiated, no claim can be made against the Town due to the breaking or malfunction of any municipal water service facility, water line or other appurtenance.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000)
Secs. 13-46—13-80. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV Sewers
Sec. 13-81. Definitions.
Sec. 13-82. Use of public sewers required.

Sec. 13-81. Definitions.
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this Article shall be as follows:
BOD (denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand ) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under the standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty degrees (20º) C expressed in milligrams per liter.
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 245
Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet outside the inner face of the building wall.
Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal.
Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce.
Industrial wastes mean the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade or business as distinct from sanitary sewage.
Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater.
pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution.
Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers with no particle greater than one-half (½) inch in any dimension.
Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights and which is controlled by public authority.
Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface and ground waters are not intentionally admitted.
Service line means the sewer line running from the premises of a user to the connection to the Town main sewer line.
Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface and storm waters as may be present.
Sewage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage.
Sewer main means a pipe or conduit belonging to the Town for carrying sewage from a user's property to the sewage treatment plant.
Sludge means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation.
Storm drain (sometimes termed storm sewer ) means a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water.
Superintendent means the Town Administrator or his or her authorized deputy agent or representative, or such other person as shall be appointed by the Board of Trustees.
Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering.
Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2012-03 §11)
Sec. 13-82. Use of public sewers required.
a) Prior to the approval of a zoning clearance for new construction, proof shall be presented that the appropriate sewer tap has been purchased.
b) It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the Town, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the Town, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste.
c) It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the Town, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the Town, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this Article.
d) Except as hereinafter provided, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
e) The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes situated within the Town and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the Town, is hereby required, at his or her expense, to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this Article within ninety (90)
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 246
days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within four hundred (400) feet of the property line.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 896 §2, 2003)
Sec. 13-83. Building sewers and connections.
a) No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining authorization from the Town Administrator and paying the appropriate sewer tap fee to the Town Clerk.
b) All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the Town from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer, and said service line shall belong to the property owner.
c) A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where review by the Town's Engineer or another consultant determines that it is infeasible to properly construct, and then the whole is considered as one (1) building sewer.
d) The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the Town. In the absence of Code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9 or the current publication of "Individual Sewage Disposal Systems" printed by the Colorado Department of Health and Environmental Services shall apply.
e) Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer.
f) No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, interior sump pumps, areaway drains or other sources of surface, runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
g) The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the Town, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9 or the current publication of "Individual Sewage Disposal Systems" printed by the Colorado Department of Health and Environmental Services. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the Superintendent before installation.
h) The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the Superintendent when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the Superintendent.
i) All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the Town.
j) Grease traps shall be installed in the waste line leading from sinks, drains and other fixtures or equipment in establishments such as restaurants, cafes, lunch counters, cafeterias, bars and clubs, hotel, hospital, sanitarium, factory or other establishments where grease may be introduced into the drainage or sewage system in quantities that can effect line stoppage or hinder sewage treatment or private sewage disposal in compliance with the currently adopted edition of the plumbing code. The Town Administrator shall mandate the frequency of clean-out in writing and may require the property owner to produce a record of cleaning. A grease trap is not required for individual dwelling units or for any private living quarters.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2012-03 §12)
Sec. 13-84. Use of the public sewers.
a) In the event of a request for a connection to permit the discharge of any substance of an unusual nature which requires a review by the Town Engineer or other consultant, the Town shall require the applicant to pay all costs for such services.
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 247
b) No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer.
c) Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the Town Administrator. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the Town Administrator, to a storm sewer or natural outlet.
d) No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described substances, materials, waters or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the Town Administrator that such wastes may harm the sewage works, including but not limited to the sewers, sewage treatment process or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream or otherwise endanger life, limb, public property or constitute a nuisance. In forming an opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewage treatment process, capacity at the wastewater treatment facility, degree of treatability of wastes at the wastewater treatment facility and other pertinent factors.
e) No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public or sanitary sewer:
1. Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, lubricating oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid, gas or pollutant which may create a fire or explosion hazard, including but not limited to waste streams with a closed cup flashpoint of less than sixty (60) degrees Celsius or one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit using the test method specified in 40 CFR, Section 261.21.
2. Any waters or wastes containing grease, oil or other substances that will solidify or become discernibly viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) degrees and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit, or any waters or wastes containing or possessing heat in amounts which will inhibit biological activity in the sewage treatment works resulting in interference. In no case shall heat be allowed in such quantities that the temperature at the waste water treatment facility exceeds one hundred four (104) degrees Fahrenheit.
3. Any waters or wastes containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether emulsified or not, in quantities capable of causing obstructions to flow, pass-through or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage treatment works. Petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral origin in amounts that will cause interference or pass-through.
4. Any waters or wastes that contain concentrated dye waste or other waste that is either highly colored or could become highly colored by reacting with other waste, and which is not removable at the wastewater treatment facility.
5. Any waters or wastes containing or which result in the presence of toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, vapors, fumes or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, which contaminate the sludge of any municipal system or injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process or constitute a hazard to the health and safety of humans or animals, create a public nuisance or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant.
6. Any waters, pollutants or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5.
7. Any solid or viscous substances in quantities or amounts of such size capable of causing obstruction of the flow in sewers, pass-through or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage system, such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair, fleshings, entrails, paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders.
8. Sludge or other material from sewage or industrial waste treatment plants or from water treatment plants, unless agreed to by the Town Administrator.
9. Water accumulated in excavations or accumulated as the result of grading, water taken from the ground by well points or any other drainage associated with construction, without prior approval by the Town.
10. Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit or exceeding any lower limit fixed by the Town to prevent odor nuisance when the
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 248
volume of heated discharge represents a significant portion of the flow through a particular sewer.
11. Any waters or wastes that contain a corrosive, noxious or malodorous gas or substance which, either singly or by reaction with other wastes, is capable of causing damage to the system or to any part thereof, of creating a public nuisance or hazard or of preventing entry into the sewers for maintenance and repair.
12. Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the Town Administrator in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations.
13. Quantities of flow, concentrations of flow or both which constitute sludge as defined in this Chapter.
14. Any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff or subsurface drainage to any sanitary sewer, unless special permission is granted in writing by the Town. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers.
15. Any pollutants, waters or wastes, including oxygen-demanding pollutants, discharged at a flow rate or pollutant concentration or in such volume which will exceed the hydraulic capacity of the wastewater facilities or which will cause interference with the wastewater treatment facility.
16. Any waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment process employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the wastewater treatment facility effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters.
17. Any trucked or hauled pollutants, except at discharge points designated by public works personnel.
18. Mass-based local limits. The following nondomestic discharge limitations are established to protect sludge quality and prevent pass-through and interference with the proper operation of the sewer works. These limits are shown in pounds per day. They reflect the total industrial contributions that can be discharged by permitted industrial users and received at the headworks of the wastewater treatment facility. These are called maximum allowable industrial loads * :

19. Ethylene glycol (antifreeze). Small amounts are considered to be one-half [½] gallon or less. Large amounts (over one-half [½] gallon) must be held for reclamation unless prior approval and instructions for discharge are obtained from the Town.
20. The following nondomestic discharge limitations are established to protect sludge quality and prevent pass through and interference with the proper operation of the sewage works. These limits are shown in maximum allowable concentrations:

21. Any waters or waste having a pH in excess of 9.5.
f) Surcharge. Industrial users discharging a nontoxic or nonhazardous wastewater that exceeds the level set forth in this Code for biological oxygen demand (BOD) and/or total suspended solids (TSS) shall be surcharged in accordance with adopted surcharge rates. Permitted industrial users shall be surcharged for BOD in excess of two hundred (200) mg/L and TSS in excess of two hundred fifty (250) mg/L. In no case shall a surcharge be allowed that may cause pass through or interference or otherwise cause a discharge of wastewater that violates any limit or prohibition specified in this Section.
g) If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the sanitary sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in Subsection (e) above and which, in the judgment of the Town Administrator, may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the Town may:
1. Reject the wastes;
2. Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers;
3. Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or
4. Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges under the provisions of Subsection (m) below.
h) If the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows is required, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the Town Administrator and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws.
i) Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the Town, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the Town utilizing the American Society of Tubing Manufacturers, the American Society of Standards and Engineering and local design standards, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
j) Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his or her expense.
k) When required by the Town, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole, together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the Town. The manhole shall be installed and maintained by the owner at his or her expense so as to be safe and accessible at all times.
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 250
l) All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this Article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of 40 CFR, Part 136, at a monitoring location specified in the permit or otherwise specified by the Town, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four-hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty-four-hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pHs are determined from periodic grab samples. All pertinent EPA standards shall be used as the criteria.
m) No statement contained in this Section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the Town and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the Town for treatment, subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern and approval by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 895 §2, 2003; Ord. 2012-03 §13)
Sec. 13-85. Sewer connections; maintenance of privies.
No person owning or occupying any lot or premises within any regularly established sewer district of the Town shall be permitted to have upon his or her premises any privy or water closet, except as the same is properly connected with a sewer, and no person shall hereafter construct within a sewer district any cesspool, but all waste, soil and drain pipes shall be connected with the sewer.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000)
Sec. 13-86. Protection from damage.
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewer works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct.
(Ord. 685 §1, 1993; Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000))
Sec. 13-87. Powers and authority of inspector.
a) The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the Town bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this Article. The Superintendent or his or her representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers, waterways or facilities for waste treatment.
b) While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in Subsection (a) above, the Superintendent or duly authorized employees of the Town shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company, the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the Town employees, and the Town shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by Town employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required in Section 13-84(h) above.
c) The Superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the Town bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the Town holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved.
(Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000)

Sec. 13-88. Service charges assessed.
a) There shall be levied and assessed upon each lot, parcel of land, building or premises having any connection with the sewer system of the Town, monthly sewer service charges computed by multiplying the EQU by the following factors to wit:
1. Single-family dwelling, 1.00 EQU.
2. Multiple-family dwellings, 0.72 times number of single-family units.
3. Hotels and motels:
a. No restaurants or kitchen, 0.36 times number of rooms;
b. With kitchenette, 0.43 times number of rooms;
c. Bed and breakfasts, 0.36 times number of rooms;
d. With restaurants, use Subparagraph (a)(3)b. above, then add rates from Paragraph (a)(4) below.
4. Restaurants:
a. Twenty-four-hour operation, 0.21 times number of seats;
b. Twelve-hour or less operation, 0.14 times number of seats;
c. Bar, no food, 0.04 times number of seats.
5. Schools:
a. No food or showers, 0.04 times number of student capacity;
b. For cafeterias, add to Subparagraph (a)(5)a. above, 0.02 times number of student capacity;
c. For showers, add to Subparagraph (a)(5)a. above, 0.02 times number of student capacity;
d. Boarding schools, 0.27 times number of student capacity.
6. Service stations:
a. Without wash rack, 1.00 EQU;
b. With wash rack, 2.3 times number of wash racks.
7. Shopping centers and stores, 0.35 times number of thousands of square feet of store space.
8. Travel trailer parks and courts (KOA and similar), 0.49 times number of trailer spaces.
9. Churches, assembly halls, theaters and arenas, 0.01 times number of seating capacity.
10. Factories, warehouses, shops and offices (not including industrial waste), 0.05 times number of employees.
11. Hospitals, 0.89 times number of bed spaces.
12. Institutions, nursing homes, 0.36 times number of residences.
13. Laundry, coin-operated, 1.34 times number of washing machines.
14. Mobile/manufactured home parks, 0.67 times number of lots or spaces.
15. Car wash, 3.5 times number of bays.
16. Fast food take-out (walk-up or drive-up):
a. Open twelve (12) or more hours, 0.1 times number of employees;
b. Open less than twelve (12) hours, 0.06 times number of employees.
(Ord. 2012-03 §14)
Secs. 13-89—13-100. Reserved.
ARTICLE V Sewer Rates
Sec. 13-101. Sewer tap fees.
Sec. 13-102. Monthly sewer charges.
Sec. 13-103. Unpaid sewer charges; lien; collection.
Secs. 13-104—13-120. Reserved.
CHAPTER 13 Municipal Utilities
Page 252
Sec. 13-101. Sewer tap fees.
A sewer tap fee (plant investment fee) shall be paid to the Town Clerk, in accordance with a fee schedule promulgated from time to time by resolution of the Board of Trustees, before any physical connection of any kind may be made to the Town's sewer system.
(Ord. 661, 1992; Ord. 790 §2, 1998; Ord. 853 §§1, 2, 2000; Ord. 2005-03 §8)
Sec. 13-102. Monthly sewer charges.
a) All premises connected to the Town sanitary sewer system shall be assessed and shall pay monthly sewer charges in accordance with this Section. The individual, individuals or entities in whose name the billing is listed by the Town or property owner shall pay the monthly sewer charges. The monthly sewer charges shall constitute a lien on the property.
b) Monthly sewer charges shall consist of three (3) components: (1) the monthly sewer service charge; and, if applicable, (2) the monthly sewer volume charge; and, if applicable, (3) the monthly high strength wastewater surcharge.
1. Monthly minimum sewer service charges. The monthly minimum sewer service charge shall be assessed and paid for each residential dwelling unit, mobile home dwelling unit, mobile/manufactured home park/subdivision, business and industry listed as an active sewer account by the Town. A schedule of monthly minimum sewer service charges shall be promulgated from time to time by resolution of the Board of Trustees.
2. Monthly sewer volume charge. The monthly sewer volume charge shall be assessed and paid for each residential dwelling unit, mobile/manufactured home park/ subdivision, business and industry connected to the Town sanitary sewer system in accordance with a fee schedule promulgated from time to time by resolution of the Board of Trustees. Said schedule shall include charges for properties located within the corporate limits of the Town, as well as for properties located beyond the corporate limits of the Town.
3. Monthly high strength wastewater surcharge. Individuals or entities found to have discharged or to be discharging wastewater having a strength in excess of that of domestic wastewater shall be assessed and billed and shall pay an additional twenty percent (20%) of the total monthly sewer charge.
4. For each multi-unit property, business or residential, a full monthly service fee shall be charged for the first unit. Each unit thereafter shall be assessed at seventy percent (70%) of the monthly service fee regardless of occupancy.
(Ord. 853 §2, 2000; Ord. 2005-03 §§9, 10; Ord. 2012-03 §15)
Sec. 13-103. Unpaid sewer charges; lien; collection.
All rates, fees, charges and assessments provided by this Article V of Chapter 13 from the time the same shall become due and payable, shall become and remain a lien on the premises until said rates, fees, charges and assessments have been paid to the Town. This lien on the premises may be foreclosed by an action at law or in equity in the name of the Town in any Court having jurisdiction thereof. If the Town must resort to court action for collection of amounts due it under this Article, the Town shall also be entitled to its reasonable attorney's fees (including legal assistance fees) and other expenses incurred in such action if the Town prevails. In the event said rates, fees, charges and assessments are not paid when due, the Town Treasurer may file a notice of such lien in the records of the Mesa County Clerk and Recorder. In addition, the Town Treasurer may certified the amount of the same to the Mesa County Treasurer, to be placed on the tax list for the current year and to be collected in the same manner as other taxes are collected, with ten percent (10%) added thereto to defray the cost of collection, pursuant to Section 31-20-105, C.R.S. All laws of this State for the assessment and collection of general taxes, including the laws for the sale of property for taxes and redemption of the same, shall apply.
(Ord. 2014-17, §2)
Secs. 13-104—13-120. Reserved.

ARTICLE I General Provisions
Sec. 14-1. Short title.
Sec. 14-2. Intent.
Sec. 14-3. Authority.
Sec. 14-4. Severability.
Sec. 14-5. Prevailing provisions.
